          "content": "# Heuristics Design & Integration Plan\n\n## Part 1: Core Heuristics\n\n### Heuristic 1: Objective Quality Score\n\n**What it measures**: Concrete, automatable code quality\n\n```rust\nstruct QualityMetrics {\n    test_pass_rate: f64,      // 0.0 to 1.0\n    coverage: f64,             // 0.0 to 1.0\n    placeholder_rate: f64,     // 0.0 to 1.0 (TODOs, stubs, etc.)\n    error_handling_rate: f64,  // 0.0 to 1.0 (try/catch, Result, etc.)\n}\n\nimpl QualityMetrics {\n    fn compute_score(&self) -> f64 {\n        0.35 * self.test_pass_rate +\n        0.30 * self.coverage +\n        0.20 * (1.0 - self.placeholder_rate) +\n        0.15 * self.error_handling_rate\n    }\n    \n    fn is_complete(&self) -> bool {\n        self.compute_score() >= 0.90\n    }\n}\n```\n\n**Why these weights**: \n- Tests passing (35%): Most objective signal\n- Coverage (30%): Ensures thoroughness\n- No placeholders (20%): Directly addresses the problem\n- Error handling (15%): Common gap in LLM code\n\n### Heuristic 2: Confidence Calibration\n\n**What it addresses**: Choice-supportive bias from Paper #8\n\n```rust\nstruct ConfidenceCalibration {\n    self_reported: f64,        // LLM's confidence\n    verifier_confidence: f64,  // Adversarial verifier's assessment\n    consistency_score: f64,    // Variance across 3 generations\n}\n\nimpl ConfidenceCalibration {\n    fn calibrated_confidence(&self) -> f64 {\n        // Discount self-reported by 20% (Paper #8 finding)\n        let discounted_self = self.self_reported * 0.8;\n        \n        // Weight verifier more heavily (adversarial signal)\n        let weighted = \n            0.3 * discounted_self +\n            0.5 * self.verifier_confidence +\n            0.2 * self.consistency_score;\n        \n        weighted\n    }\n    \n    fn overconfidence_detected(&self) -> bool {\n        // Large gap between self and verifier\n        (self.self_reported - self.verifier_confidence) > 0.3\n    }\n}\n```\n\n### Heuristic 3: Consistency Checker\n\n**What it addresses**: Output variance from Paper #9\n\n```rust\nstruct ConsistencyCheck {\n    variants: Vec<String>,  // 3 generations of same requirement\n}\n\nimpl ConsistencyCheck {\n    fn compute_consistency(&self) -> f64 {\n        // Measure structural similarity (not exact match)\n        let similarities = self.pairwise_similarities();\n        similarities.iter().sum::<f64>() / similarities.len() as f64\n    }\n    \n    fn pairwise_similarities(&self) -> Vec<f64> {\n        let mut sims = Vec::new();\n        for i in 0..self.variants.len() {\n            for j in (i+1)..self.variants.len() {\n                sims.push(self.structural_similarity(\n                    &self.variants[i], \n                    &self.variants[j]\n                ));\n            }\n        }\n        sims\n    }\n    \n    fn structural_similarity(&self, a: &str, b: &str) -> f64 {\n        // AST-based similarity, not string matching\n        // Returns 0.0 to 1.0\n        ast_similarity(a, b)\n    }\n}\n```\n\n### Heuristic 4: Verification Gradient\n\n**What it measures**: Concrete gaps to fix (not abstract \"quality\")\n\n```rust\nstruct VerificationGradient {\n    missing_error_handling: Vec<String>,  // Specific functions/blocks\n    incomplete_implementations: Vec<String>,  // TODOs, stubs\n    failing_tests: Vec<String>,  // Specific test names\n    uncovered_branches: Vec<String>,  // Specific code paths\n    verifier_concerns: Vec<String>,  // Specific issues found\n}\n\nimpl VerificationGradient {\n    fn magnitude(&self) -> f64 {\n        // Total number of issues\n        (self.missing_error_handling.len() +\n         self.incomplete_implementations.len() +\n         self.failing_tests.len() +\n         self.uncovered_branches.len() +\n         self.verifier_concerns.len()) as f64\n    }\n    \n    fn is_converged(&self) -> bool {\n        self.magnitude() == 0.0\n    }\n    \n    fn prioritized_issues(&self) -> Vec<Issue> {\n        // Order by impact: failing tests > missing error handling > coverage\n        let mut issues = Vec::new();\n        \n        for test in &self.failing_tests {\n            issues.push(Issue::FailingTest(test.clone(), Priority::High));\n        }\n        for handler in &self.missing_error_handling {\n            issues.push(Issue::MissingErrorHandling(handler.clone(), Priority::Medium));\n        }\n        // ... etc\n        \n        issues\n    }\n}\n```\n\n### Heuristic 5: Iteration Dynamics\n\n**What it tracks**: Progress over time (not just current state)\n\n```rust\nstruct IterationDynamics {\n    history: Vec<IterationState>,\n}\n\nstruct IterationState {\n    iteration: u32,\n    quality_score: f64,\n    gradient_magnitude: f64,\n    confidence: f64,\n    timestamp: DateTime,\n}\n\nimpl IterationDynamics {\n    fn is_improving(&self) -> bool {\n        if self.history.len() < 2 { return true; }\n        \n        let recent = &self.history[self.history.len()-3..];\n        let scores: Vec<f64> = recent.iter().map(|s| s.quality_score).collect();\n        \n        // Check if trend is upward\n        is_increasing(&scores)\n    }\n    \n    fn is_oscillating(&self) -> bool {\n        if self.history.len() < 4 { return false; }\n        \n        let recent = &self.history[self.history.len()-4..];\n        let scores: Vec<f64> = recent.iter().map(|s| s.quality_score).collect();\n        \n        // Check for up-down-up-down pattern\n        (scores[1] > scores[0] && scores[2] < scores[1] && scores[3] > scores[2]) ||\n        (scores[1] < scores[0] && scores[2] > scores[1] && scores[3] < scores[2])\n    }\n    \n    fn is_stuck(&self) -> bool {\n        if self.history.len() < 3 { return false; }\n        \n        let recent = &self.history[self.history.len()-3..];\n        let scores: Vec<f64> = recent.iter().map(|s| s.quality_score).collect();\n        \n        // No meaningful change\n        variance(&scores) < 0.01\n    }\n    \n    fn velocity(&self) -> f64 {\n        // Rate of improvement\n        if self.history.len() < 2 { return 0.0; }\n        \n        let last = self.history.last().unwrap();\n        let prev = &self.history[self.history.len()-2];\n        \n        (last.quality_score - prev.quality_score) / \n        (last.timestamp - prev.timestamp).as_secs_f64()\n    }\n}\n```\n\n## Part 2: Decision Logic (No Thresholds)\n\n### Strategy Selection\n\n```rust\nenum Strategy {\n    DeepReasoning,      // Long CoT, extensive exploration\n    Incremental,        // One component at a time\n    TestFirst,          // Generate tests, then implementation\n    AdversarialVerify,  // Focus on breaking the code\n}\n\nimpl Strategy {\n    fn select(\n        quality: &QualityMetrics,\n        confidence: &ConfidenceCalibration,\n        gradient: &VerificationGradient,\n        dynamics: &IterationDynamics,\n    ) -> Strategy {\n        // Rule 1: If stuck, change approach\n        if dynamics.is_stuck() {\n            return Strategy::Incremental;\n        }\n        \n        // Rule 2: If oscillating, need deeper reasoning\n        if dynamics.is_oscillating() {\n            return Strategy::DeepReasoning;\n        }\n        \n        // Rule 3: If overconfident, need adversarial check\n        if confidence.overconfidence_detected() {\n            return Strategy::AdversarialVerify;\n        }\n        \n        // Rule 4: If tests failing, focus on tests\n        if !gradient.failing_tests.is_empty() {\n            return Strategy::TestFirst;\n        }\n        \n        // Default: continue current approach\n        Strategy::Incremental\n    }\n}\n```\n\n### Stopping Condition\n\n```rust\nstruct StoppingCondition;\n\nimpl StoppingCondition {\n    fn should_stop(\n        quality: &QualityMetrics,\n        gradient: &VerificationGradient,\n        dynamics: &IterationDynamics,\n    ) -> StopDecision {\n        // Natural stopping: gradient converged\n        if gradient.is_converged() && quality.is_complete() {\n            return StopDecision::Success;\n        }\n        \n        // Divergence: not making progress\n        if dynamics.is_stuck() && dynamics.history.len() > 5 {\n            return StopDecision::Stuck;\n        }\n        \n        // Oscillation: can't converge\n        if dynamics.is_oscillating() && dynamics.history.len() > 6 {\n            return StopDecision::Oscillating;\n        }\n        \n        // Budget exhausted\n        if dynamics.history.len() > 10 {\n            return StopDecision::IterationLimit;\n        }\n        \n        // Continue\n        StopDecision::Continue\n    }\n}\n\nenum StopDecision {\n    Success,\n    Stuck,\n    Oscillating,\n    IterationLimit,\n    Continue,\n}\n```\n\n### Escalation Logic\n\n```rust\nstruct EscalationLogic;\n\nimpl EscalationLogic {\n    fn should_escalate(\n        stop_decision: &StopDecision,\n        quality: &QualityMetrics,\n        dynamics: &IterationDynamics,\n    ) -> Option<EscalationType> {\n        match stop_decision {\n            StopDecision::Success => None,\n            \n            StopDecision::Stuck => {\n                if quality.compute_score() < 0.5 {\n                    Some(EscalationType::RequestHelp)\n                } else {\n                    Some(EscalationType::SuggestReview)\n                }\n            }\n            \n            StopDecision::Oscillating => {\n                Some(EscalationType::StrategyChange)\n            }\n            \n            StopDecision::IterationLimit => {\n                if quality.compute_score() < 0.7 {\n                    Some(EscalationType::HardStop)\n                } else {\n                    Some(EscalationType::SuggestReview)\n                }\n            }\n            \n            StopDecision::Continue => None,\n        }\n    }\n}\n\nenum EscalationType {\n    RequestHelp,      // \"I need guidance on X\"\n    SuggestReview,    // \"Please review, I'm at 75% confidence\"\n    StrategyChange,   // \"Switching to incremental approach\"\n    HardStop,         // \"Cannot complete, here's what's missing\"\n}\n```\n\n## Part 3: Integration with Q CLI\n\n### Session Metadata Extension\n\n```rust\n// In session metadata custom_fields\n{\n    \"verification_state\": {\n        \"current_iteration\": 3,\n        \"quality_metrics\": {\n            \"test_pass_rate\": 0.85,\n            \"coverage\": 0.72,\n            \"placeholder_rate\": 0.05,\n            \"error_handling_rate\": 0.60\n        },\n        \"confidence\": {\n            \"self_reported\": 0.90,\n            \"verifier_confidence\": 0.65,\n            \"consistency_score\": 0.80,\n            \"calibrated\": 0.71\n        },\n        \"gradient\": {\n            \"missing_error_handling\": [\"handle_auth_failure\", \"validate_input\"],\n            \"failing_tests\": [\"test_edge_case_empty_input\"],\n            \"magnitude\": 3.0\n        },\n        \"dynamics\": {\n            \"improving\": true,\n            \"oscillating\": false,\n            \"stuck\": false,\n            \"velocity\": 0.05\n        },\n        \"current_strategy\": \"Incremental\"\n    }\n}\n```\n\n### Skill Integration\n\n```rust\n// New skill type: VerificationSkill\npub struct VerificationSkill {\n    quality_analyzer: QualityAnalyzer,\n    confidence_calibrator: ConfidenceCalibrator,\n    consistency_checker: ConsistencyChecker,\n    gradient_computer: GradientComputer,\n}\n\nimpl Skill for VerificationSkill {\n    fn execute(&self, context: &SkillContext) -> SkillResult {\n        // 1. Analyze code quality\n        let quality = self.quality_analyzer.analyze(&context.code);\n        \n        // 2. Calibrate confidence\n        let confidence = self.confidence_calibrator.calibrate(\n            context.self_confidence,\n            &context.code,\n        );\n        \n        // 3. Check consistency\n        let consistency = self.consistency_checker.check(&context.code);\n        \n        // 4. Compute gradient\n        let gradient = self.gradient_computer.compute(\n            &quality,\n            &context.tests,\n        );\n        \n        // 5. Update session state\n        context.session.update_verification_state(\n            quality,\n            confidence,\n            gradient,\n        );\n        \n        // 6. Decide next action\n        let decision = self.decide_next_action(context);\n        \n        SkillResult::new(decision)\n    }\n}\n```\n\n### Workflow Integration\n\n```yaml\n# verification_workflow.yaml\nname: \"code_generation_with_verification\"\ndescription: \"Generate code with continuous verification\"\n\nsteps:\n  - skill: \"conversation\"\n    input: \"Understand requirement\"\n    output: \"requirement_spec\"\n  \n  - skill: \"code_inline\"\n    input: \"{{requirement_spec}}\"\n    output: \"initial_code\"\n  \n  - skill: \"verification\"\n    input: \"{{initial_code}}\"\n    output: \"verification_result\"\n    loop:\n      condition: \"verification_result.should_continue\"\n      max_iterations: 10\n      steps:\n        - skill: \"code_inline\"\n          input: \"Fix: {{verification_result.gradient.prioritized_issues}}\"\n          output: \"improved_code\"\n        \n        - skill: \"verification\"\n          input: \"{{improved_code}}\"\n          output: \"verification_result\"\n  \n  - skill: \"conversation\"\n    input: \"Present results: {{verification_result}}\"\n    condition: \"verification_result.needs_escalation\"\n```\n\n### Context Window Management\n\n```rust\nimpl ContextManager {\n    fn position_verification_context(\n        &self,\n        context: &mut Context,\n        verification_state: &VerificationState,\n    ) {\n        let lrel = context.current_tokens as f64 / context.max_tokens as f64;\n        \n        // Based on Paper #3: primacy bias strongest at Lrel < 0.5\n        if lrel < 0.5 {\n            // Position verification criteria at start (0-10% of context)\n            context.prepend(format!(\n                \"<verification_criteria>\\n{}\\n</verification_criteria>\",\n                verification_state.gradient.prioritized_issues()\n            ));\n        } else {\n            // Compact and reset\n            self.compact_with_verification_anchors(context, verification_state);\n        }\n    }\n    \n    fn compact_with_verification_anchors(\n        &self,\n        context: &mut Context,\n        verification_state: &VerificationState,\n    ) {\n        // Keep:\n        // 1. Original requirement\n        // 2. All failing tests\n        // 3. All identified gaps\n        // 4. Current gradient\n        \n        let anchors = vec![\n            context.original_requirement.clone(),\n            verification_state.gradient.to_string(),\n            verification_state.dynamics.summary(),\n        ];\n        \n        context.compact_preserving(anchors);\n    }\n}\n```\n\n## Part 4: Data Collection Integration\n\n### Episode Logging\n\n```rust\npub struct EpisodeLogger {\n    storage: EpisodeStorage,\n    current_episode: Option<Episode>,\n}\n\npub struct Episode {\n    id: String,\n    timestamp: DateTime,\n    \n    // Input\n    requirement: String,\n    context: CodeContext,\n    \n    // Trajectory\n    iterations: Vec<IterationSnapshot>,\n    \n    // Outcome\n    final_quality: QualityMetrics,\n    final_confidence: ConfidenceCalibration,\n    stop_decision: StopDecision,\n    escalation: Option<EscalationType>,\n    \n    // Ground truth (collected later)\n    user_feedback: Option<UserFeedback>,\n}\n\npub struct IterationSnapshot {\n    iteration: u32,\n    timestamp: DateTime,\n    \n    // State\n    code: String,\n    quality: QualityMetrics,\n    confidence: ConfidenceCalibration,\n    gradient: VerificationGradient,\n    dynamics: IterationDynamics,\n    \n    // Decision\n    strategy: Strategy,\n    action_taken: String,\n}\n\nimpl EpisodeLogger {\n    pub fn start_episode(&mut self, requirement: String, context: CodeContext) {\n        self.current_episode = Some(Episode {\n            id: generate_id(),\n            timestamp: now(),\n            requirement,\n            context,\n            iterations: Vec::new(),\n            // ... rest initialized\n        });\n    }\n    \n    pub fn log_iteration(&mut self, snapshot: IterationSnapshot) {\n        if let Some(episode) = &mut self.current_episode {\n            episode.iterations.push(snapshot);\n        }\n    }\n    \n    pub fn end_episode(&mut self, outcome: EpisodeOutcome) {\n        if let Some(mut episode) = self.current_episode.take() {\n            episode.final_quality = outcome.quality;\n            episode.final_confidence = outcome.confidence;\n            episode.stop_decision = outcome.stop_decision;\n            episode.escalation = outcome.escalation;\n            \n            // Save to disk\n            self.storage.save(episode);\n        }\n    }\n}\n```\n\n### Storage Structure\n\n```\n.amazonq/\n├── sessions/\n│   └── {conversation_id}/\n│       └── workspace/\n└── training_data/\n    ├── episodes/\n    │   ├── 2025-11-03/\n    │   │   ├── ep_abc123.json\n    │   │   └── ep_def456.json\n    │   └── index.db\n    └── config.json\n```\n\n### Automatic Metrics Collection\n\n```rust\nimpl Episode {\n    fn collect_automatic_metrics(&mut self) {\n        // Objective metrics - no human input needed\n        self.final_quality = QualityMetrics {\n            test_pass_rate: self.compute_test_pass_rate(),\n            coverage: self.compute_coverage(),\n            placeholder_rate: self.scan_placeholders(),\n            error_handling_rate: self.scan_error_handling(),\n        };\n        \n        // Temporal metrics\n        self.total_time = self.iterations.last().timestamp - self.timestamp;\n        self.total_iterations = self.iterations.len();\n        \n        // Convergence metrics\n        self.converged = matches!(self.stop_decision, StopDecision::Success);\n        self.final_gradient_magnitude = self.iterations.last()\n            .map(|i| i.gradient.magnitude())\n            .unwrap_or(0.0);\n    }\n}\n```\n\n### Optional User Feedback\n\n```rust\npub struct UserFeedback {\n    // Collected after episode completes\n    accepted: Option<bool>,\n    satisfaction: Option<u8>,  // 1-5\n    issues: Vec<IssueType>,\n    \n    // Collected later (temporal validation)\n    still_in_use_after_24h: Option<bool>,\n    edits_made: Vec<Edit>,\n}\n\nimpl EpisodeLogger {\n    pub fn request_feedback(&self, episode_id: &str) {\n        // Non-blocking, optional\n        println!(\"Rate this code generation? [1-5 or skip]\");\n        // Store response if provided\n    }\n}\n```\n\n### Query Interface\n\n```rust\npub struct EpisodeQuery {\n    storage: EpisodeStorage,\n}\n\nimpl EpisodeQuery {\n    pub fn high_quality_episodes(&self) -> Vec<Episode> {\n        self.storage.query()\n            .filter(|e| e.final_quality.compute_score() > 0.9)\n            .filter(|e| e.converged)\n            .filter(|e| e.iterations.len() <= 5)\n            .collect()\n    }\n    \n    pub fn failed_episodes(&self) -> Vec<Episode> {\n        self.storage.query()\n            .filter(|e| e.final_quality.compute_score() < 0.5)\n            .or_filter(|e| matches!(e.stop_decision, StopDecision::Stuck))\n            .collect()\n    }\n    \n    pub fn export_training_data(&self) -> Vec<TrainingExample> {\n        self.storage.query()\n            .map(|e| e.to_training_example())\n            .collect()\n    }\n}\n```\n\n## Summary\n\n**Heuristics (5 core components)**:\n1. Objective Quality Score (tests, coverage, placeholders, error handling)\n2. Confidence Calibration (discount self-assessment, weight verifier)\n3. Consistency Checker (variance across generations)\n4. Verification Gradient (concrete list of issues to fix)\n5. Iteration Dynamics (progress tracking, oscillation/stuck detection)\n\n**Decision Logic (no arbitrary thresholds)**:\n- Strategy selection based on dynamics patterns\n- Natural stopping when gradient converges\n- Escalation based on stop decision + quality\n\n**Integration**:\n- Session metadata stores verification state\n- New VerificationSkill executes heuristics\n- Workflows loop until convergence\n- Context manager positions verification info optimally\n\n**Data Collection**:\n- Episode logging captures full trajectory\n- Automatic metrics (no human input needed)\n- Optional user feedback\n- Query interface for analysis\n\n**Next steps**: Which component should we detail first? The verification skill implementation, or the episode logging system?"

nx-text-3xl nx-border-neutral-200/70 contrast-more:nx-border-neutral-400 dark:nx-border-primary-100/10 contrast-more:dark:nx-border-neutral-400\"><strong>What is Context Engineering?</strong><a href=\"#what-is-context-engineering\" id=\"what-is-context-engineering\" class=\"subheading-anchor\" aria-label=\"Permalink for this section\"></a></h2>\n<p class=\"nx-mt-6 nx-leading-7 first:nx-mt-0\">A few years ago, many, even top AI researchers, claimed that prompt engineering would be dead by now.</p>\n<p class=\"nx-mt-6 nx-leading-7 first:nx-mt-0\">Obviously, they were very wrong, and in fact, prompt engineering is now even more important than ever. It is so important that it is now being rebranded as <em><strong>context engineering</strong></em>.</p>\n<p class=\"nx-mt-6 nx-leading-7 first:nx-mt-0\">Yes, another fancy term to describe the important process of tuning the instructions and relevant context that an LLM needs to perform its tasks effectively.</p>\n<p class=\"nx-mt-6 nx-leading-7 first:nx-mt-0\">Much has been written already about context engineering (<a href=\"https://x.com/ankrgyl/status/1913766591910842619\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noreferrer\" class=\"nx-text-primary-600 nx-underline nx-decoration-from-font [text-underline-position:from-font]\">Ankur Goyal<span class=\"nx-sr-only nx-select-none\"> (opens in a new tab)</span></a>, <a href=\"https://cognition.ai/blog/dont-build-multi-agents\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noreferrer\" class=\"nx-text-primary-600 nx-underline nx-decoration-from-font [text-underline-position:from-font]\">Walden Yan<span class=\"nx-sr-only nx-select-none\"> (opens in a new tab)</span></a>, <a href=\"https://x.com/tobi/status/1935533422589399127\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noreferrer\" class=\"nx-text-primary-600 nx-underline nx-decoration-from-font [text-underline-position:from-font]\">Tobi Lutke<span class=\"nx-sr-only nx-select-none\"> (opens in a new tab)</span></a>, and <a href=\"https://x.com/karpathy/status/1937902205765607626\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noreferrer\" class=\"nx-text-primary-600 nx-underline nx-decoration-from-font [text-underline-position:from-font]\">Andrej Karpathy<span class=\"nx-sr-only nx-select-none\"> (opens in a new tab)</span></a>), but I wanted to write about my thoughts on the topic and show you a concrete step-by-step guide putting context engineering into action in developing an AI agent workflow.</p>\n<p class=\"nx-mt-6 nx-leading-7 first:nx-mt-0\">I am not entirely sure who coined context engineering, but we will build on this figure from <a href=\"https://x.com/dexhorthy/status/1933283008863482067\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noreferrer\" class=\"nx-text-primary-600 nx-underline nx-decoration-from-font [text-underline-position:from-font]\">Dex Horthy<span class=\"nx-sr-only nx-select-none\"> (opens in a new tab)</span></a> that briefly explains a bit about what context engineering is.</p>\n<p                 "file_text": "# Context Engineering System for LLM Code Generation Quality Control\n\n**Version**: 1.0  \n**Date**: 2025-11-03  \n**Status**: Design Phase\n\n---\n\n## Executive Summary\n\nThis document describes a **context engineering system** for Q CLI that addresses systematic failures in LLM code generation: 15-30% placeholder rates, 40-60% missing error handling, and false completion claims.\n\n**Core Insight**: LLMs fail not because they can't generate good code, but because they receive poor context. By engineering what information enters the context window, when it enters, and how it's structured, we can dramatically improve code quality.\n\n**Approach**: Heuristic-based context optimization with data collection for future ML models.\n\n**Constraints**: API-only access, no fine-tuning, real-time requirements.\n\n---\n\n## Table of Contents\n\n1. [Problem Statement](#problem-statement)\n2. [Context Engineering Framework](#context-engineering-framework)\n3. [Core Heuristics](#core-heuristics)\n4. [System Architecture](#system-architecture)\n5. [Integration with Q CLI](#integration-with-q-cli)\n6. [Data Collection Strategy](#data-collection-strategy)\n7. [Research Foundation](#research-foundation)\n8. [Implementation Plan](#implementation-plan)\n\n---\n\n## Problem Statement\n\n### Observed Failures\n\n- **Placeholder Rate**: 15-30% of generated code contains TODOs, stubs, or incomplete implementations\n- **Error Handling**: 40-50% missing proper error handling\n- **False Completions**: 60-70% claim completion when code is incomplete\n- **Iteration Cycles**: 5-10 rounds of back-and-forth to reach acceptable quality\n\n### Root Cause\n\n**Choice-Supportive Bias** (Kumaran et al., 2025): LLMs inflate confidence in their own outputs, creating resistance to change.\n\n**Hypersensitivity to Criticism** (Kumaran et al., 2025): When contradicted (e.g., test failures), LLMs overreact and abandon correct code.\n\n**Consistency Issues** (Saxena et al., 2024): Same requirement produces inconsistent outputs, indicating unreliable internal models.\n\n**Verification Gap**: LLMs optimize for appearing correct rather than being correct.\n\n---\n\n## Context Engineering Framework\n\n### Definition\n\n**Context Engineering**: The process of designing and optimizing instructions and relevant context for LLMs to perform tasks effectively.\n\nThis encompasses:\n- **Prompt Engineering**: Instruction design and structure\n- **Context Window Management**: What information to include, when, and where\n- **Structured I/O**: Format enforcement and validation\n- **Dynamic Context**: Conditional information injection\n- **State Management**: Historical context and revision tracking\n- **Evaluation**: Measuring context effectiveness\n\n### Core Principle\n\n> \"Context engineering is not just about optimizing your prompt; it's about choosing the right context for the goals you are targeting.\"\n\n### Key Insight from Research\n\n**Positional Bias** (Liu et al., 2024): 30% accuracy difference between information at position 0-10% vs middle of context at Lrel = 0.06. Primacy bias weakens at Lrel ≥ 0.5.\n\n**Implication**: Position verification criteria at start of context when Lrel < 0.5. Compact at Lrel = 0.5 to maintain positioning effectiveness.\n\n---\n\n## Core Heuristics\n\n### Heuristic 1: Objective Quality Metrics\n\n**What it measures**: Concrete, automatable code quality signals.\n\n```rust\nstruct QualityMetrics {\n    test_pass_rate: f64,      // 0.0 to 1.0\n    coverage: f64,             // 0.0 to 1.0\n    placeholder_rate: f64,     // 0.0 to 1.0 (TODOs, stubs)\n    error_handling_rate: f64,  // 0.0 to 1.0 (try/catch, Result)\n}\n\nimpl QualityMetrics {\n    fn compute_score(&self) -> f64 {\n        0.35 * self.test_pass_rate +\n        0.30 * self.coverage +\n        0.20 * (1.0 - self.placeholder_rate) +\n        0.15 * self.error_handling_rate\n    }\n}\n```\n\n**Rationale**: \n- Tests passing (35%): Most objective signal\n- Coverage (30%): Ensures thoroughness\n- No placeholders (20%): Directly addresses the problem\n- Error handling (15%): Common gap in LLM code\n\n**Context Engineering Application**: These metrics determine what context to inject next.\n\n---\n\n### Heuristic 2: Confidence Calibration\n\n**What it addresses**: Choice-supportive bias and overconfidence.\n\n```rust\nstruct ConfidenceCalibration {\n    self_reported: f64,        // LLM's confidence\n    verifier_confidence: f64,  // Adversarial verifier\n    consistency_score: f64,    // Variance across 3 generations\n}\n\nimpl ConfidenceCalibration {\n    fn calibrated_confidence(&self) -> f64 {\n        // Discount self-reported by 20% (Kumaran et al. finding)\n        let discounted_self = self.self_reported * 0.8;\n        \n        // Weight verifier more heavily (adversarial signal)\n        0.3 * discounted_self +\n        0.5 * self.verifier_confidence +\n        0.2 * self.consistency_score\n    }\n    \n    fn overconfidence_detected(&self) -> bool {\n        (self.self_reported - self.verifier_confidence) > 0.3\n    }\n}\n```\n\n**Research Foundation**: \n- Kumaran et al. (2025): LLMs boost confidence in initial answers by ~20%\n- Adversarial verification provides independent signal\n\n**Context Engineering Application**: When overconfidence detected, inject adversarial verification results into context at high-priority position.\n\n---\n\n### Heuristic 3: Consistency Validation\n\n**What it addresses**: Output variance and unreliable generation.\n\n```rust\nstruct ConsistencyCheck {\n    variants: Vec<String>,  // 3 generations of same requirement\n}\n\nimpl ConsistencyCheck {\n    fn compute_consistency(&self) -> f64 {\n        // AST-based structural similarity\n        let similarities = self.pairwise_similarities();\n        similarities.iter().sum::<f64>() / similarities.len() as f64\n    }\n    \n    fn structural_similarity(&self, a: &str, b: &str) -> f64 {\n        // Compare AST structure, not string matching\n        ast_similarity(a, b)\n    }\n}\n```\n\n**Research Foundation**: Saxena et al. (2024) - Consistency evaluation methodology.\n\n**Context Engineering Application**: Low consistency (< 0.5) indicates ambiguous requirements. Inject clarifying context or examples.\n\n---\n\n### Heuristic 4: Verification Gradient\n\n**What it measures**: Concrete, actionable gaps to fix.\n\n```rust\nstruct VerificationGradient {\n    missing_error_handling: Vec<String>,\n    incomplete_implementations: Vec<String>,\n    failing_tests: Vec<String>,\n    uncovered_branches: Vec<String>,\n    verifier_concerns: Vec<String>,\n}\n\nimpl VerificationGradient {\n    fn magnitude(&self) -> f64 {\n        (self.missing_error_handling.len() +\n         self.incomplete_implementations.len() +\n         self.failing_tests.len() +\n         self.uncovered_branches.len() +\n         self.verifier_concerns.len()) as f64\n    }\n    \n    fn is_converged(&self) -> bool {\n        self.magnitude() == 0.0\n    }\n    \n    fn prioritized_issues(&self) -> Vec<Issue> {\n        // Failing tests > missing error handling > coverage\n        let mut issues = Vec::new();\n        for test in &self.failing_tests {\n            issues.push(Issue::FailingTest(test.clone(), Priority::High));\n        }\n        // ... etc\n        issues\n    }\n}\n```\n\n**Context Engineering Application**: This IS the context we inject. Not vague \"improve code\" but specific \"fix test_auth_failure, add error handling to validate_input()\".\n\n**Structured Output**: Use delimiters and format enforcement:\n```\n<verification_criteria>\nPriority 1 (High): Fix failing test: test_auth_failure\nPriority 2 (Medium): Add error handling: validate_input()\nPriority 3 (Low): Increase coverage: handle_edge_case()\n</verification_criteria>\n```\n\n---\n\n### Heuristic 5: Iteration Dynamics\n\n**What it tracks**: Progress patterns over time.\n\n```rust\nstruct IterationDynamics {\n    history: Vec<IterationState>,\n}\n\nstruct IterationState {\n    iteration: u32,\n    quality_score: f64,\n    gradient_magnitude: f64,\n    confidence: f64,\n    timestamp: DateTime,\n}\n\nimpl IterationDynamics {\n    fn is_improving(&self) -> bool {\n        let recent = &self.history[self.history.len()-3..];\n        let scores: Vec<f64> = recent.iter().map(|s| s.quality_score).collect();\n        is_increasing(&scores)\n    }\n    \n    fn is_oscillating(&self) -> bool {\n        // up-down-up-down pattern\n        let recent = &self.history[self.history.len()-4..];\n        let scores: Vec<f64> = recent.iter().map(|s| s.quality_score).collect();\n        (scores[1] > scores[0] && scores[2] < scores[1] && scores[3] > scores[2]) ||\n        (scores[1] < scores[0] && scores[2] > scores[1] && scores[3] < scores[2])\n    }\n    \n    fn is_stuck(&self) -> bool {\n        let recent = &self.history[self.history.len()-3..];\n        let scores: Vec<f64> = recent.iter().map(|s| s.quality_score).collect();\n        variance(&scores) < 0.01\n    }\n}\n```\n\n**Context Engineering Application**: \n- **Stuck**: Inject different context (examples, alternative approaches)\n- **Oscillating**: Inject stabilizing context (constraints, explicit requirements)\n- **Improving**: Continue current context strategy\n\n---\n\n### Heuristic 6: Context Effectiveness Tracking\n\n**What it measures**: Whether context is helping or diluting.\n\n```rust\nstruct ContextMetrics {\n    size_tokens: usize,\n    relevance_score: f64,   // how much context was actually used\n    quality_delta: f64,      // improvement from this context\n    \n    fn efficiency(&self) -> f64 {\n        self.quality_delta / (self.size_tokens as f64)\n    }\n    \n    fn is_diluted(&self, prev: &Self) -> bool {\n        // Context grew but quality didn't improve\n        self.size_tokens > prev.size_tokens * 1.2 &&\n        self.quality_delta < 0.05\n    }\n}\n```\n\n**Research Foundation**: Context Engineering Guide - \"Context can dilute or become inefficient (i.e., be filled with stale and irrelevant information).\"\n\n**Context Engineering Application**: Trigger compaction not just at Lrel = 0.5, but also when efficiency drops.\n\n---\n\n## System Architecture\n\n### Context Window Management\n\n**Positioning Strategy** (based on Liu et al., 2024):\n\n```rust\nimpl ContextManager {\n    fn position_verification_context(\n        &self,\n        context: &mut Context,\n        verification_state: &VerificationState,\n    ) {\n        let lrel = context.current_tokens as f64 / context.max_tokens as f64;\n        \n        if lrel < 0.5 {\n            // Primacy bias strongest - position at start (0-10%)\n            context.prepend(format!(\n                \"<verification_criteria>\\n{}\\n</verification_criteria>\",\n                verification_state.gradient.prioritized_issues()\n            ));\n        } else {\n            // Compact and reset to maintain positioning effectiveness\n            self.compact_with_verification_anchors(context, verification_state);\n        }\n    }\n    \n    fn compact_with_verification_anchors(\n        &self,\n        context: &mut Context,\n        verification_state: &VerificationState,\n    ) {\n        // Keep critical information:\n        let anchors = vec![\n            context.original_requirement.clone(),\n            verification_state.gradient.to_string(),\n            verification_state.dynamics.summary(),\n        ];\n        \n        context.compact_preserving(anchors);\n        // Reset to Lrel ~0.25\n    }\n}\n```\n\n### Dynamic Context Injection\n\n**Conditional Information** (based on Context Engineering Guide):\n\n```rust\nfn build_context(&self, requirement: &str, state: &VerificationState) -> Context {\n    let mut ctx = Context::new();\n    \n    // Always include\n    ctx.add_requirement(requirement);\n    ctx.add_verification_gradient(&state.gradient);\n    \n    // Conditional - only when needed\n    if requires_date_info(requirement) {\n        ctx.add_current_datetime();\n    }\n    \n    if state.confidence.overconfidence_detected() {\n        ctx.add_adversarial_verification();\n    }\n    \n    if state.dynamics.is_stuck() {\n        ctx.add_alternative_approaches();\n    }\n    \n    if has_similar_past_work(requirement) {\n        ctx.add_cached_examples();  // RAG\n    }\n    \n    ctx\n}\n```\n\n### Structured Output Enforcement\n\n**Format Validation** (based on Context Engineering Guide):\n\n```rust\n#[derive(Serialize, Deserialize)]\nstruct VerificationOutput {\n    #[serde(rename = \"quality_score\")]\n    quality: f64,\n    \n    #[serde(rename = \"issues\")]\n    gradient: Vec<Issue>,\n    \n    #[serde(rename = \"next_action\")]\n    recommendation: Action,\n    \n    #[serde(rename = \"confidence\")]\n    self_confidence: f64,\n}\n\n// Provide schema to LLM in context\nfn get_output_schema() -> String {\n    r#\"\n    {\n      \"quality_score\": 0.75,\n      \"issues\": [\n        {\"type\": \"failing_test\", \"name\": \"test_auth\", \"priority\": 1},\n        {\"type\": \"missing_error_handling\", \"location\": \"validate_input\", \"priority\": 2}\n      ],\n      \"next_action\": \"fix_tests\",\n      \"confidence\": 0.80\n    }\n    \"#.to_string()\n}\n```\n\n---\n\n## Integration with Q CLI\n\n### Session Metadata Extension\n\n```rust\n// In session metadata custom_fields\n{\n    \"context_engineering_state\": {\n        \"current_iteration\": 3,\n        \"quality_metrics\": {\n            \"test_pass_rate\": 0.85,\n            \"coverage\": 0.72,\n            \"placeholder_rate\": 0.05,\n            \"error_handling_rate\": 0.60,\n            \"score\": 0.73\n        },\n        \"confidence\": {\n            \"self_reported\": 0.90,\n            \"verifier_confidence\": 0.65,\n            \"consistency_score\": 0.80,\n            \"calibrated\": 0.71\n        },\n        \"gradient\": {\n            \"missing_error_handling\": [\"handle_auth_failure\", \"validate_input\"],\n            \"failing_tests\": [\"test_edge_case_empty_input\"],\n            \"magnitude\": 3.0\n        },\n        \"dynamics\": {\n            \"improving\": true,\n            \"oscillating\": false,\n            \"stuck\": false\n        },\n        \"context_metrics\": {\n                 "file_text": "# Context Engineering System for LLM Code Generation Quality Control\n\n**Version**: 1.0  \n**Date**: 2025-11-03  \n**Status**: Design Phase\n\n---\n\n## Executive Summary\n\nThis document describes a **context engineering system** for Q CLI that addresses systematic failures in LLM code generation: 15-30% placeholder rates, 40-60% missing error handling, and false completion claims.\n\n**Core Insight**: LLMs fail not because they can't generate good code, but because they receive poor context. By engineering what information enters the context window, when it enters, and how it's structured, we can dramatically improve code quality.\n\n**Approach**: Heuristic-based context optimization with data collection for future ML models.\n\n**Constraints**: API-only access, no fine-tuning, real-time requirements.\n\n---\n\n## Table of Contents\n\n1. [Problem Statement](#problem-statement)\n2. [Context Engineering Framework](#context-engineering-framework)\n3. [Core Heuristics](#core-heuristics)\n4. [System Architecture](#system-architecture)\n5. [Integration with Q CLI](#integration-with-q-cli)\n6. [Data Collection Strategy](#data-collection-strategy)\n7. [Research Foundation](#research-foundation)\n8. [Implementation Plan](#implementation-plan)\n\n---\n\n## Problem Statement\n\n### Observed Failures\n\n- **Placeholder Rate**: 15-30% of generated code contains TODOs, stubs, or incomplete implementations\n- **Error Handling**: 40-50% missing proper error handling\n- **False Completions**: 60-70% claim completion when code is incomplete\n- **Iteration Cycles**: 5-10 rounds of back-and-forth to reach acceptable quality\n\n### Root Cause\n\n**Choice-Supportive Bias** (Kumaran et al., 2025): LLMs inflate confidence in their own outputs, creating resistance to change.\n\n**Hypersensitivity to Criticism** (Kumaran et al., 2025): When contradicted (e.g., test failures), LLMs overreact and abandon correct code.\n\n**Consistency Issues** (Saxena et al., 2024): Same requirement produces inconsistent outputs, indicating unreliable internal models.\n\n**Verification Gap**: LLMs optimize for appearing correct rather than being correct.\n\n---\n\n## Context Engineering Framework\n\n### Definition\n\n**Context Engineering**: The process of designing and optimizing instructions and relevant context for LLMs to perform tasks effectively.\n\nThis encompasses:\n- **Prompt Engineering**: Instruction design and structure\n- **Context Window Management**: What information to include, when, and where\n- **Structured I/O**: Format enforcement and validation\n- **Dynamic Context**: Conditional information injection\n- **State Management**: Historical context and revision tracking\n- **Evaluation**: Measuring context effectiveness\n\n### Core Principle\n\n> \"Context engineering is not just about optimizing your prompt; it's about choosing the right context for the goals you are targeting.\"\n\n### Key Insight from Research\n\n**Positional Bias** (Liu et al., 2024): 30% accuracy difference between information at position 0-10% vs middle of context at Lrel = 0.06. Primacy bias weakens at Lrel ≥ 0.5.\n\n**Implication**: Position verification criteria at start of context when Lrel < 0.5. Compact at Lrel = 0.5 to maintain positioning effectiveness.\n\n---\n\n## Core Heuristics\n\n### Heuristic 1: Objective Quality Metrics\n\n**What it measures**: Concrete, automatable code quality signals.\n\n```rust\nstruct QualityMetrics {\n    test_pass_rate: f64,      // 0.0 to 1.0\n    coverage: f64,             // 0.0 to 1.0\n    placeholder_rate: f64,     // 0.0 to 1.0 (TODOs, stubs)\n    error_handling_rate: f64,  // 0.0 to 1.0 (try/catch, Result)\n}\n\nimpl QualityMetrics {\n    fn compute_score(&self) -> f64 {\n        0.35 * self.test_pass_rate +\n        0.30 * self.coverage +\n        0.20 * (1.0 - self.placeholder_rate) +\n        0.15 * self.error_handling_rate\n    }\n}\n```\n\n**Rationale**: \n- Tests passing (35%): Most objective signal\n- Coverage (30%): Ensures thoroughness\n- No placeholders (20%): Directly addresses the problem\n- Error handling (15%): Common gap in LLM code\n\n**Context Engineering Application**: These metrics determine what context to inject next.\n\n---\n\n### Heuristic 2: Confidence Calibration\n\n**What it addresses**: Choice-supportive bias and overconfidence.\n\n```rust\nstruct ConfidenceCalibration {\n    self_reported: f64,        // LLM's confidence\n    verifier_confidence: f64,  // Adversarial verifier\n    consistency_score: f64,    // Variance across 3 generations\n}\n\nimpl ConfidenceCalibration {\n    fn calibrated_confidence(&self) -> f64 {\n        // Discount self-reported by 20% (Kumaran et al. finding)\n        let discounted_self = self.self_reported * 0.8;\n        \n        // Weight verifier more heavily (adversarial signal)\n        0.3 * discounted_self +\n        0.5 * self.verifier_confidence +\n        0.2 * self.consistency_score\n    }\n    \n    fn overconfidence_detected(&self) -> bool {\n        (self.self_reported - self.verifier_confidence) > 0.3\n    }\n}\n```\n\n**Research Foundation**: \n- Kumaran et al. (2025): LLMs boost confidence in initial answers by ~20%\n- Adversarial verification provides independent signal\n\n**Context Engineering Application**: When overconfidence detected, inject adversarial verification results into context at high-priority position.\n\n---\n\n### Heuristic 3: Consistency Validation\n\n**What it addresses**: Output variance and unreliable generation.\n\n```rust\nstruct ConsistencyCheck {\n    variants: Vec<String>,  // 3 generations of same requirement\n}\n\nimpl ConsistencyCheck {\n    fn compute_consistency(&self) -> f64 {\n        // AST-based structural similarity\n        let similarities = self.pairwise_similarities();\n        similarities.iter().sum::<f64>() / similarities.len() as f64\n    }\n    \n    fn structural_similarity(&self, a: &str, b: &str) -> f64 {\n        // Compare AST structure, not string matching\n        ast_similarity(a, b)\n    }\n}\n```\n\n**Research Foundation**: Saxena et al. (2024) - Consistency evaluation methodology.\n\n**Context Engineering Application**: Low consistency (< 0.5) indicates ambiguous requirements. Inject clarifying context or examples.\n\n---\n\n### Heuristic 4: Verification Gradient\n\n**What it measures**: Concrete, actionable gaps to fix.\n\n```rust\nstruct VerificationGradient {\n    missing_error_handling: Vec<String>,\n    incomplete_implementations: Vec<String>,\n    failing_tests: Vec<String>,\n    uncovered_branches: Vec<String>,\n    verifier_concerns: Vec<String>,\n}\n\nimpl VerificationGradient {\n    fn magnitude(&self) -> f64 {\n        (self.missing_error_handling.len() +\n         self.incomplete_implementations.len() +\n         self.failing_tests.len() +\n         self.uncovered_branches.len() +\n         self.verifier_concerns.len()) as f64\n    }\n    \n    fn is_converged(&self) -> bool {\n        self.magnitude() == 0.0\n    }\n    \n    fn prioritized_issues(&self) -> Vec<Issue> {\n        // Failing tests > missing error handling > coverage\n        let mut issues = Vec::new();\n        for test in &self.failing_tests {\n            issues.push(Issue::FailingTest(test.clone(), Priority::High));\n        }\n        // ... etc\n        issues\n    }\n}\n```\n\n**Context Engineering Application**: This IS the context we inject. Not vague \"improve code\" but specific \"fix test_auth_failure, add error handling to validate_input()\".\n\n**Structured Output**: Use delimiters and format enforcement:\n```\n<verification_criteria>\nPriority 1 (High): Fix failing test: test_auth_failure\nPriority 2 (Medium): Add error handling: validate_input()\nPriority 3 (Low): Increase coverage: handle_edge_case()\n</verification_criteria>\n```\n\n---\n\n### Heuristic 5: Iteration Dynamics\n\n**What it tracks**: Progress patterns over time.\n\n```rust\nstruct IterationDynamics {\n    history: Vec<IterationState>,\n}\n\nstruct IterationState {\n    iteration: u32,\n    quality_score: f64,\n    gradient_magnitude: f64,\n    confidence: f64,\n    timestamp: DateTime,\n}\n\nimpl IterationDynamics {\n    fn is_improving(&self) -> bool {\n        let recent = &self.history[self.history.len()-3..];\n        let scores: Vec<f64> = recent.iter().map(|s| s.quality_score).collect();\n        is_increasing(&scores)\n    }\n    \n    fn is_oscillating(&self) -> bool {\n        // up-down-up-down pattern\n        let recent = &self.history[self.history.len()-4..];\n        let scores: Vec<f64> = recent.iter().map(|s| s.quality_score).collect();\n        (scores[1] > scores[0] && scores[2] < scores[1] && scores[3] > scores[2]) ||\n        (scores[1] < scores[0] && scores[2] > scores[1] && scores[3] < scores[2])\n    }\n    \n    fn is_stuck(&self) -> bool {\n        let recent = &self.history[self.history.len()-3..];\n        let scores: Vec<f64> = recent.iter().map(|s| s.quality_score).collect();\n        variance(&scores) < 0.01\n    }\n}\n```\n\n**Context Engineering Application**: \n- **Stuck**: Inject different context (examples, alternative approaches)\n- **Oscillating**: Inject stabilizing context (constraints, explicit requirements)\n- **Improving**: Continue current context strategy\n\n---\n\n### Heuristic 6: Context Effectiveness Tracking\n\n**What it measures**: Whether context is helping or diluting.\n\n```rust\nstruct ContextMetrics {\n    size_tokens: usize,\n    relevance_score: f64,   // how much context was actually used\n    quality_delta: f64,      // improvement from this context\n    \n    fn efficiency(&self) -> f64 {\n        self.quality_delta / (self.size_tokens as f64)\n    }\n    \n    fn is_diluted(&self, prev: &Self) -> bool {\n        // Context grew but quality didn't improve\n        self.size_tokens > prev.size_tokens * 1.2 &&\n        self.quality_delta < 0.05\n    }\n}\n```\n\n**Research Foundation**: Context Engineering Guide - \"Context can dilute or become inefficient (i.e., be filled with stale and irrelevant information).\"\n\n**Context Engineering Application**: Trigger compaction not just at Lrel = 0.5, but also when efficiency drops.\n\n---\n\n## System Architecture\n\n### Context Window Management\n\n**Positioning Strategy** (based on Liu et al., 2024):\n\n```rust\nimpl ContextManager {\n    fn position_verification_context(\n        &self,\n        context: &mut Context,\n        verification_state: &VerificationState,\n    ) {\n        let lrel = context.current_tokens as f64 / context.max_tokens as f64;\n        \n        if lrel < 0.5 {\n            // Primacy bias strongest - position at start (0-10%)\n            context.prepend(format!(\n                \"<verification_criteria>\\n{}\\n</verification_criteria>\",\n                verification_state.gradient.prioritized_issues()\n            ));\n        } else {\n            // Compact and reset to maintain positioning effectiveness\n            self.compact_with_verification_anchors(context, verification_state);\n        }\n    }\n    \n    fn compact_with_verification_anchors(\n        &self,\n        context: &mut Context,\n        verification_state: &VerificationState,\n    ) {\n        // Keep critical information:\n        let anchors = vec![\n            context.original_requirement.clone(),\n            verification_state.gradient.to_string(),\n            verification_state.dynamics.summary(),\n        ];\n        \n        context.compact_preserving(anchors);\n        // Reset to Lrel ~0.25\n    }\n}\n```\n\n### Dynamic Context Injection\n\n**Conditional Information** (based on Context Engineering Guide):\n\n```rust\nfn build_context(&self, requirement: &str, state: &VerificationState) -> Context {\n    let mut ctx = Context::new();\n    \n    // Always include\n    ctx.add_requirement(requirement);\n    ctx.add_verification_gradient(&state.gradient);\n    \n    // Conditional - only when needed\n    if requires_date_info(requirement) {\n        ctx.add_current_datetime();\n    }\n    \n    if state.confidence.overconfidence_detected() {\n ctx.add_cached_examples();  // RAG\n    }\n    \n    ctx\n}\n```\n\n### Structured Output Enforcement\n\n**Format Validation** (based on Context Engineering Guide):\n\n```rust\n#[derive(Serialize, Deserialize)]\nstruct VerificationOutput {\n    #[serde(rename = \"quality_score\")]\n    quality: f64,\n    \n    #[serde(rename = \"issues\")]\n    gradient: Vec<Issue>,\n    \n    #[serde(rename = \"next_action\")]\n    recommendation: Action,\n    \n    #[serde(rename = \"confidence\")]\n    self_confidence: f64,\n}\n\n// Provide schema to LLM in context\nfn get_output_schema() -> String {\n    r#\"\n    {\n      \"quality_score\": 0.75,\n      \"issues\": [\n        {\"type\": \"failing_test\", \"name\": \"test_auth\", \"priority\": 1},\n        {\"type\": \"missing_error_handling\", \"location\": \"validate_input\", \"priority\": 2}\n      ],\n      \"next_action\": \"fix_tests\",\n      \"confidence\": 0.80\n    }\n    \"#.to_string()\n}\n```\n\n---\n\n## Integration with Q \"{{improved_code}}\"\n          output: \"verification_result\"\n```\n\n---\n\n## Data Collection Strategy\n\n### Episode Logging\n\n```rust\npub struct Episode {\n    id: String,\n    timestamp: DateTime,\n    \n    // Input\n    requirement: String,\n    context: CodeContext,\n    \n    // Trajectory\n    iterations: Vec<IterationSnapshot>,\n    \n    // Context Engineering Metrics\n    context_evolution: Vec<ContextMetrics>,\n    \n    // Outcome\n    final_quality: QualityMetrics,\n    final_confidence: ConfidenceCalibration,\n    converged: bool,\n    \n    // Ground truth (collected later)\n    user_feedback: Option<UserFeedback>,\n}\n\npub struct IterationSnapshot {\n    iteration: u32,\n    timestamp: DateTime,\n    \n    // State\n    code: String,\n    quality: QualityMetrics,\n    confidence: ConfidenceCalibration,\n    gradient: VerificationGradient,\n    \n    // Context Engineering\n    context_size: usize,\n    context_lrel: f64,\n    context_efficiency: f64,\n    \n    // Decision\n    action_taken: String,\n}\n```\n\n### Automatic Metrics Collection\n\n```rust\nimpl Episode {\n    fn collect_automatic_metrics(&mut self) {\n        // Objective metrics - no human input needed\n        self.final_quality = QualityMetrics {\n            test_pass_rate: self.compute_test_pass_rate(),\n            coverage: self.compute_coverage(),\n            placeholder_rate: self.scan_placeholders(),\n            error_handling_rate: self.scan_error_handling(),\n        };\n        \n        // Context effectiveness\n        self.context_effectiveness = self.analyze_context_evolution();\n        \n        // Convergence\n        self.converged = self.iterations.last()\n            .map(|i| i.gradient.magnitude() == 0.0)\n            .unwrap_or(false);\n    }\n}\n```\n\n### Quality Assurance\n\n**Multi-Signal Triangulation**:\n\n```rust\nfn is_high_quality_episode(episode: &Episode) -> bool {\n    episode.final_quality.compute_score() > 0.9\n    && episode.converged\n    && episode.iterations.len() <= 5\n    && episode.context_effectiveness > 0.001\n}\n```\n\n**Temporal Validation**:\n\n```rust\nstruct TemporalValidation {\n    immediate: Outcome,\n    one_day: Option<Outcome>,\n    one_week: Option<Outcome>,\n}\n\n// Code that survives a week is probably good\nfn final_quality(tv: &TemporalValidation) -> Option<Quality> {\n    match tv.one_week {\n        Some(outcome) if outcome.still_in_use => Some(Quality::High),\n        Some(outcome) if outcome.was_replaced => Some(Quality::Low),\n        _ => None\n    }\n}\n```\n\n### Storage Structure\n\n```\n.amazonq/\n├── sessions/\n│   └── {conversation_id}/\n│       └── workspace/\n└── training_data/\n    ├── episodes/\n    │   ├── 2025-11-03/\n    │   │   ├── ep_abc123.json\n    │   │   └── ep_def456.json\n    │   └── index.db\n    └── config.json\n```\n\n---\n\n## Research Foundation\n\n### Papers Analyzed\n\n1. **Positional Bias** (Liu et al., 2024) - arxiv.org/pdf/2508.07479\n   - 30% accuracy difference based on position\n   - Compact at Lrel = 0.5\n\n2. **Overconfidence/Underconfidence** (Kumaran et al., 2025) - arxiv.org/pdf/2507.03120\n   - Choice-supportive bias: 20% confidence inflation\n   - Hypersensitivity to criticism\n\n3. **Consistency and Reasoning** (Saxena et al., 2024) - arxiv.org/pdf/2404.16478v1\n   - Consistency evaluation methodology\n   - Reasoning capability assessment\n\n4. **Context Engineering Guide** - promptingguide.ai/guides/context-engineering-guide\n   - Structured I/O enforcement\n   - Dynamic context injection\n   - Context effectiveness measurement\n\n5. **TAG - Tagging-Augmented Generation** - arxiv.org/pdf/2510.22956\n   - XML tagging for structured context\n   - 17% improvement at 32K tokens\n\n6. **DeepAgent** - arxiv.org/pdf/2510.21618\n   - Memory folding for context compaction\n   - Advantage attribution\n\n7. **Long CoT Survey** - arxiv.org/pdf/2503.09567\n   - Deep reasoning modulation\n   - Exploration vs exploitation\n\n8. **Prompt Evolution** - arxiv.org/pdf/2412.17298\n   - Only 21.9% of changes documented\n   - Need for systematic tracking\n\n9. **Planning Tokens** - arxiv.org/pdf/2310.05707\n   - Special tokens for guidance\n   - 3.3% improvement\n\n---\n\n## Implementation Plan\n\n### Phase 1: Core Heuristics (Weeks 1-2)\n\n**Week 1**: Quality metrics + Confidence calibration\n- Implement QualityMetrics analyzer\n- Implement ConfidenceCalibration\n- Unit tests\n\n**Week 2**: Gradient + Dynamics\n- Implement VerificationGradient\n- Implement IterationDynamics\n- Integration tests\n\n### Phase 2: Context Management (Weeks 3-4)\n\n**Week 3**: Context window management\n- Implement ContextManager\n- Positioning strategy (Lrel-based)\n- Compaction with anchors\n\n**Week 4**: Dynamic context injection\n- Conditional information\n- Structured output enforcement\n- RAG integration\n\n### Phase 3: Q CLI Integration (Weeks 5-6)\n\n**Week 5**: Session metadata + Skill\n- Extend session metadata\n- Implement ContextEngineeringSkill\n- Workflow integration\n\n**Week 6**: Testing + Refinement\n- End-to-end tests\n- Performance optimization\n- Documentation\n\n### Phase 4: Data Collection (Weeks 7-8)\n\n**Week 7**: Episode logging\n- Implement EpisodeLogger\n- Storage infrastructure\n- Query interface\n\n**Week 8**: Metrics + Validation\n- Automatic metrics collection\n- Quality assurance\n- Export functionality\n\n---\n\n## Success Metrics\n\n### Primary Metrics\n\n- **Placeholder Rate**: 15-30% → <5%\n- **Coverage**: 40-60% → >90%\n- **Completion Accuracy**: 30-40% → >90%\n- **Iterations**: 5-10 → 2-4\n\n### Secondary Metrics\n\n- **Context Efficiency**: >0.001 quality improvement per 1K tokens\n- **Convergence Rate**: >70% of episodes converge\n- **Time Overhead**: <20% increase vs baseline\n- **Episode Quality**: >60% high-quality episodes after 3 months\n\n### Context Engineering Specific\n\n- **Lrel at Convergence**: <0.5 (effective positioning maintained)\n- **Context Dilution Rate**: <10% of episodes\n- **Dynamic Injection Accuracy**: >80% (only inject when needed)\n\n---\n\n## Appendix: Decision Logic\n\n### Strategy Selection\n\n```rust\nenum Strategy {\n    DeepReasoning,\n    Incremental,\n    TestFirst,\n    AdversarialVerify,\n}\n\nimpl Strategy {\n    fn select(\n        quality: &QualityMetrics,\n        confidence: &ConfidenceCalibration,\n        gradient: &VerificationGradient,\n        dynamics: &IterationDynamics,\n    ) -> Strategy {\n        if dynamics.is_stuck() {\n            return Strategy::Incremental;\n        }\n        if dynamics.is_oscillating() {\n            return Strategy::DeepReasoning;\n        }\n        if confidence.overconfidence_detected() {\n            return Strategy::AdversarialVerify;\n        }\n        if !gradient.failing_tests.is_empty() {\n            return Strategy::TestFirst;\n        }\n        Strategy::Incremental\n    }\n}\n```\n\n### Stopping Condition\n\n```rust\nenum StopDecision {\n    Success,\n    Stuck,\n    Oscillating,\n    IterationLimit,\n    Continue,\n}\n\nimpl StopDecision {\n    fn evaluate(\n        quality: &QualityMetrics,\n        gradient: &VerificationGradient,\n        dynamics: &IterationDynamics,\n    ) -> Self {\n        if gradient.is_converged() && quality.compute_score() > 0.9 {\n            return Self::Success;\n        }\n        if dynamics.is_stuck() && dynamics.history.len() > 5 {\n            return Self::Stuck;\n        }\n        if dynamics.is_oscillating() && dynamics.history.len() > 6 {\n            return Self::Oscillating;\n        }\n        if dynamics.history.len() > 10 {\n            return Self::IterationLimit;\n        }\n        Self::Continue\n    }\n}\n```\n\n---\n\n## Conclusion\n\nThis context engineering system addresses LLM code generation failures through systematic optimization of what information enters the context window, when, and how it's structured.\n\n**Key Innovation**: Not trying to change the LLM, but engineering the context it receives to compensate for known biases (choice-supportive, hypersensitivity) and leverage known strengths (positional bias, structured outputs).\n\n**Practical Approach**: Heuristic-based system that works today, with data collection for ML-based improvements tomorrow.\n\n**Integration**: Extends Q CLI naturally through session metadata, skills, and workflows without replacing existing components.\n\n**Validation**: Comprehensive metrics and episode logging enable continuous improvement and eventual transition to learned models.\n"

Context Engineering Guide\n**URL**: https://www.promptingguide.ai/guides/context-engineering-guide  \n**Date**: 2025  \n**Authors**: DAIR.AI (Prompt Engineering Guide)  \n**Key Contributions**:\n- Reframes prompt engineering as context engineering\n- Structured inputs/outputs with delimiters and format enforcement\n- Dynamic context injection (only include what's needed)\n- RAG & memory for caching and efficiency\n- State management and historical context\n- Context effectiveness measurement and dilution detection\n- Evaluation as core component, not optional\n\n**Relevance to Design**:\n- **Primary framework**: Our system IS context engineering\n- **Structured outputs**: Enforce format, don't hope for it (verification gradient as structured JSON)\n- **Dynamic context**: Conditional injection based on state (overconfidence → adversarial verification)\n- **Context dilution**: Track efficiency (quality_delta / tokens), compact when inefficient\n- **Positioning**: Verification criteria at start when Lrel < 0.5\n- **Evaluation**: Episode logging measures context effectiveness over time\n\n**Critical Quotes**:\n> \"Context engineering is not just about optimizing your prompt; it's about choosing the right context for the goals you are targeting.\"\n\n> \"Context can dilute or become inefficient (i.e., be filled with stale and irrelevant information), which requires special evaluation workflows to capture these issues.\"\n\n---"

Trajectory Format\n\n```rust\npub struct RLTrajectory {\n    episode_id: String,\n    \n    // MDP Components\n    states: Vec<State>,\n    actions: Vec<Action>,\n    rewards: Vec<f64>,\n    next_states: Vec<State>,\n    dones: Vec<bool>,\n    \n    // Additional Context\n    advantages: Option<Vec<f64>>,  // Computed post-hoc\n    returns: Option<Vec<f64>>,     // Computed post-hoc\n    \n    // Metadata\n    total_reward: f64,\n    trajectory_length: usize,\n    success: bool,\n}\n\npub struct State {\n    // Code being verified\n    code: String,\n    code_embedding:  // Why this action\n}\n```\n\n### Reward Function Design\n\n**Objective**: Reward verifier for finding real issues, penalize false positives.\n\n```rust\npub struct RewardCalculator;\n\nimpl RewardCalculator {\n    fn compute_reward(\n        action: &Action,\n        next_state: &State,\n        ground_truth: &GroundTruth,\n    ) -> f64 {\n        match action.action_type {\n            ActionType::FlagMissingErrorHandling { location, .. } => {\n                if ground_truth.has_missing_error_handling(&location) {\n                    // True positive: Found real issue\n                    10.0 * action.parameters.confidence\n                } else {\n                    // False positive: Flagged non-issue\n                    -5.0 * action.parameters.confidence\n                }\n            }\n            \n            ActionType::FlagIncompleteImplementation { location, .. } => {\n                if ground_truth.is_incomplete(&location) {\n                    15.0 * action.parameters.confidence  // High reward\n                } else {\n                    -7.0 * action.parameters.confidence\n                }\n            }\n            \n            ActionType::FlagTestGap { scenario, .. } => {\n                if ground_truth.missing_test_for(&scenario) {\n                    8.0 * action.parameters.confidence\n                } else {\n                    -4.0 * action.parameters.confidence\n                }\n            }\n            \n            ActionType::ApproveCode => {\n                if ground_truth.is_actually_complete() {\n                    // Correctly approved complete code\n                    20.0\n                } else {\n                    // Missed issues - big penalty\n                    -30.0 * (1.0 - ground_truth.completeness_score())\n                }\n            }\n            \n            ActionType::Escalate { .. } => {\n                // Small penalty for escalation (should try to verify first)\n                -2.0\n            }\n            \n            _ => 0.0,\n        }\n    }\n    \n    fn compute_shaped_reward(\n        action: &Action,\n        state: &State,\n        next_state: &State,\n    ) -> f64 {\n        // Reward shaping: encourage progress\n        let quality_improvement = \n            next_state.quality_metrics.compute_score() - \n            state.quality_metrics.compute_score();\n        \n        // Small reward for improving quality\n        quality_improvement * 5.0\n    }\n}\n```\n\n### Ground Truth Collection\n\n**Challenge**: How do we know if verifier found a \"real\" issue?\n\n**Strategy 1: Temporal Validation**\n```rust\npub struct GroundTruth {\n    // Collected after episode completes\n    human_edits: Vec<Edit>,\n    human_added_error_handling: Vec<String>,\n    human_added_tests: Vec<String>,\n    human_fixed_bugs: Vec<Bug>,\n    \n    // Collected after deployment\n    production_errors: Vec<Error>,\n    code_still_in_use: bool,\n    code_was_replaced: bool,\n}\n\nimpl GroundTruth {\n    fn has_missing_error_handling(&self, location: &str) -> bool {\n        self.human_edits.iter().any(|edit| {\n            edit.edit_type == EditType::AddErrorHandling &&\n            edit.location.contains(location)\n        })\n    }\n    \n    fn is_incomplete(&self, location: &str) -> bool {\n        self.human_edits.iter().any(|edit| {\n            edit.edit_type == EditType::CompleteImplementation &&\n            edit.location.contains(location)\n        })\n    }\n    \n    fn is_actually_complete(&self) -> bool {\n        self.human_edits.is_empty() &&\n        self.production_errors.is_empty() &&\n        self.code_still_in_use\n    }\n}\n```\n\n**Strategy 2: Comparative Labeling**\n```rust\npub struct ComparativeLabel {\n    episode_a: String,\n    episode_b: String,\n    \n    // Which verifier found more real issues?\n    better_verifier: VerifierID,\n    \n    // Confidence in this label\n    confidence: f64,\n}\n\n// Easier for humans: \"Which verification was better?\"\n// Rather than: \"Was this specific flag correct?\"\n```\n\n**Strategy 3: Test validate_test_gap_flag(\n        code: &str,\n        flagged_scenario: &str,\n    ) -> ValidationResult {\n        let generated_test = generate_test_for_scenario(code, flagged_scenario);\n        let result = execute_test(&generated_test);\n        \n        ValidationResult {\n            verifier_was_correct: !result.passed,\n            confidence: result.confidence,\n        }\n    }\n}\n```\n\n### Data Collection During Execution\n\n```rust\npub struct RLDataCollector {\n    current_trajectory: Option<RLTrajectory>,\n    state_buffer: Vec<State>,\n    action_buffer: Vec<Action>,\n}\n\nimpl RLDataCollector {\n    pub fn record_state(&mut self, state: State) {\n        self.state_buffer.push(state);\n    }\n    \n    pub fn record_action(&mut self, action: Action) {\n        self.action_buffer.push(action);\n    }\n    \n    pub fn record_reward(&mut self, reward: f64) {\n        if let Some(traj) = &mut self.current_trajectory {\n            traj.rewards.push(reward);\n        }\n    }\n    \n    pub fn finalize_trajectory(&mut self, ground_truth: GroundTruth) -> RLTrajectory {\n        let mut trajectory = RLTrajectory {\n          dones: Vec::new(),\n            advantages: None,\n            returns: None,\n            total_reward: 0.0,\n            trajectory_length: self.state_buffer.len(),\n            success: &self.action_buffer[i],\n                &self.state_buffer[i + 1],\n                &ground_truth,\n            );\n            trajectory.rewards.push(reward);\n            trajectory.total_reward += reward;\n        }\n        \n        // Compute next_states and dones\n        for i in 0..self.state_buffer.len() - 1 {\n            trajectory.next_states.push(self.state_buffer[i + 1].clone());\n            trajectory.dones.push(false);\n        }\n        trajectory.dones.push(true);\n        \n        // Compute advantages and returns (for PPO)\n        trajectory.advantages = Some(self.compute_advantages(&trajectory));\n        trajectory.returns = Some(self.compute_returns(&trajectory));\n        \n        trajectory.success = ground_truth.is_actually_complete();\n        \n        trajectory\n    }\n    \n    fn compute_advantages(&self, traj: &RLTrajectory) -> Vec<f64> {\n        // GAE (Generalized Advantage Estimation)\n        let gamma = 0.99;\n        let lambda = 0.95;\n        \n        let mut advantages = Vec::new();\n        let mut gae = 0.0;\n        \n        for i in (0..traj.rewards.len()).rev() {\n            let delta = traj.rewards[i] + \n                        gamma * self.value_estimate(&traj.next_states[i]) - \n                        self.value_estimate(&traj.states[i]);\n            \n            gae = delta + gamma * lambda * gae;\n            advantages.insert(0, gae);\n        }\n        \n        advantages\n    }\n    \n    fn compute_returns(&self, traj: &RLTrajectory) -> Vec<f64> {\n        let gamma = 0.99;\n        let mut returns = Vec::new();\n        let mut g = 0.0;\n        \n        for reward in traj.rewards.iter().rev() {\n            g = reward + gamma * g;\n            returns.insert(0, g);\n        }\n        \n        returns\n    }\n    \n    fn value_estimate(&self, state: &State) -> f64 {\n        // Placeholder: would use learned value function\n        // For now, use heuristic\n        state.quality_metrics.compute_score()\n    }\n}\n```\n\n### Storage Format\n\n**JSONL for efficient Training Pipeline\n\n```rust\npub struct RLTrainingPipeline {\n    trajectories: Vec<RLTrajectory>,\n}\n\nimpl RLTrainingPipeline {\n    pub fn load_trajectories(&mut self, date_range: DateRange) -> Result<()> {\n        // Load from .amazonq/training_data/rl_trajectories/\n        let files = self.find_trajectory_files(date_range)?;\n        \n        for file in files {\n            let traj = self.parse_trajectory_file(file)?;\n            self.trajectories.push(traj);\n        }\n        \n        Ok(())\n    }\n    \n    pub fn filter_high_quality(&mut self) {\n        // Only train on high-quality trajectories\n        self.trajectories.retain(|traj| {\n            traj.success &&\n            traj.total_reward > 50.0 &&\n            traj.trajectory_length < 20\n        });\n    }\n    \n    pub fn export_for_training(&self, format: TrainingFormat) -> Result<Vec<u8>> {\n        match format {\n            TrainingFormat::PyTorch => self.export_pytorch(),\n            TrainingFormat::TensorFlow => self.export_tensorflow(),\n            TrainingFormat::JAX => self.export_jax(),\n        }\n    }\n    \n    fn export_pytorch(&self) -> Result<Vec<u8>> {\n        // Export as PyTorch-compatible format\n        // states: Tensor[N, state_dim]\n        // actions: Tensor[N, action_dim]\n        // rewards: Tensor[N]\n        // advantages: Tensor[N]\n        // returns: Tensor[N]\n        \n        let mut data = HashMap::new();\n        \n        let states: Vec<Vec<f64>> = self.trajectories.iter()\n            .flat_map(|t| t.states.iter().map(|s| self.state_to_vector(s)))\n            .collect();\n        \n        let actions: Vec<Vec<f64>> = self.trajectories.iter()\n            .flat_map(|t| t.actions.iter().map(|a| self.action_to_vector(a)))\n            .collect();\n        \n        data.insert(\"states\", states);\n        data.insert(\"actions\", actions);\n        // ... etc\n        \n        Ok(serde_json::to_vec(&data)?)\n    }\n}\n```\n\n### Adversarial Training Strategy\n\n**Two-Player Game**:\n\n```rust\npub struct AdversarialTraining {\n    generator: GeneratorPolicy,  // Generates code\n    verifier: VerifierPolicy,    // Finds gaps\n}\n\nimpl AdversarialTraining {\n    pub fn train_step(&mut self, batch: &[RLTrajectory]) {\n        // 1. Train verifier to find gaps\n        let verifier_loss = self.train_verifier(batch);\n        \n        // 2. Train generator to fool verifier (while still being correct)\n        let generator_loss = self.train_generator(batch);\n        \n        // 3. Alternate updates (like GAN training)\n        self.verifier.update(verifier_loss);\n        self.generator.update(generator_loss);\n    }\n    \n    fn train_verifier(&mut self, batch: &[RLTrajectory]) -> f64 {\n        // Maximize reward for finding real issues\n        // Minimize false positives\n        \n        let mut loss = 0.0;\n        \n        for traj in batch {\n            for i in 0..traj.actions.len() {\n                let predicted_value = self.verifier.forward(&traj.states[i]);\n                let target = traj.advantages.as_ref().unwrap()[i];\n                \n                loss += (predicted_value - target).powi(2);\n            }\n        }\n        \n        loss / batch.len() as f64\n    }\n    \n    fn train_generator(&mut self, batch: &[RLTrajectory]) -> f64 {\n        // Reward: Generate code that passes verifier AND is actually correct\n        // Penalty: Generate code that verifier catches OR has real issues\n        \n        let mut loss = 0.0;\n        \n        for traj in batch {\n            // If verifier approved and code was actually good → reward\n            // If verifier caught issues that were real → penalty\n            // If verifier missed issues → penalty (but less)\n            \n            let verifier_approved = traj.actions.iter().any(|a| {\n                matches!(a.action_type, ActionType::ApproveCode)\n            });\n            \n            if verifier_approved && traj.success {\n                loss -= 10.0;  // Good: fooled verifier correctly\n            } else if !verifier_approved && !traj.success {\n                loss += 5.0;   // Bad: verifier caught real issues\n            }\n        }\n        \n        loss / batch.len() as f64\n    }\n}\n```\n\n### Integration with Heuristic System\n\n**Hybrid Approach**:\n\n```rust\npub enum VerifierMode {\n    Heuristic,           // Current rule-based\n    Learned,             // RL-trained model\n    Ensemble,            // Combine both\n}\n\npub struct HybridVerifier {\n    mode: VerifierMode,\n    heuristic_verifier: HeuristicVerifier,\n    learned_verifier: Option<LearnedVerifier>,\n}\n\nimpl HybridVerifier {\n    pub fn verify(&self, code: &str, state: &State) -> VerificationResult {\n        match self.mode {\n            VerifierMode::Heuristic => {\n                self.heuristic_verifier.verify(code, state)\n            }\n            \n            VerifierMode::Learned => {\n                self.learned_verifier.as_ref()\n                    .expect(\"Learned verifier not loaded\")\n                    .verify(code, state)\n            }\n            \n            VerifierMode::Ensemble => {\n                let heuristic_result = self.heuristic_verifier.verify(code, state);\n                let learned_result = self.learned_verifier.as_ref()\n                    .expect(\"Learned verifier not loaded\")\n                    .verify(code, state);\n                \n                // Combine results (e.g., union of issues found)\n                self.combine_results(heuristic_result, learned_result)\n            }\n        }\n    }\n}\n```\n\n### Deployment Strategy\n\n**Phase 1 (Months 0-6)**: Heuristic only, collect data  \n**Phase 2 (Months 6-9)**: Train initial RL verifier offline  \n**Phase 3 (Months 9-12)**: A/B test heuristic vs learned  \n**Phase 4 (Months 12+)**: Ensemble or full learned deployment\n\n### Data Quality for RL\n\n**Requirements**:\n- **Diverse**: Cover many code patterns, requirements,   if traj.total_reward.abs() > 1000.0 {\n            issues.push(\"Total reward suspiciously high\");\n        }\n        \n        // Check 3: States and actions align\n        if traj.states.len() != traj.actions.len() + 1 {\n            issues.push(\"State/action mismatch\");\n        }\n        \n        // Check 4: Ground truth exists\n        if traj.rewards.iter().all(|&r| r == 0.0) {\n            issues.push(\"No ground truth rewards\");\n        }\n        \n        ValidationResult {\n            valid: issues.is_empty(),\n            issues,\n        }\n    }\n}\n```\n\n---\n\n##
