Critic Models (Self-Critique)\n\n### What They Are\n\nModels trained to find flaws in their own outputs.\n\n**Training**:\n```\nInput: (requirement, code)\nOutput: list of issues found\n```\n\n**Use case**: Adversarial verification - actively look for problems.\n\n### Examples\n\n**Self-Refine (Madaan et al., 2023)**:\n- Uses same LLM as generator\n- Prompts it to critique its own output\n- Iteratively refines\n- +20% improvement\n\n**Constitutional AI (Anthropic)**:\n- Model critiques itself based on \"constitution\" (principles)\n- Revises output to fix issues\n- Used in Claude\n\n**Critic-GPT (OpenAI, 2024)**:\n- GPT-4 fine-tuned to find bugs in code\n- Trained on synthetic bugs + human labels\n- Finds bugs humans miss 20% of the time\n\n### How to Use for Your System\n\n```rust\npub struct CriticModel {\n    model: LlamaModel,\n}\n\nimpl CriticModel {\n    pub fn critique(&self, requirement: &str, code: &str) -> Vec<Issue> {\n        let prompt = format!(\n            \"You are a code critic. Find ALL issues in this code.\n            \n            Requirement: {}\n            \n            Code:\n            {}\n            \n            List every issue you find:\n            1. Missing error handling in...\n            2. Incomplete implementation of...\n            3. Edge case not handled:...\",\n            requirement, code\n        );\n        \n        let critique = self.model.generate(&prompt);\n        parse_issues_from_critique(&critique)\n    }\n}\n\n// Use as adversarial verifier\nfn verify_with_critic(\n    requirement: &str,\n    code: &str,\n    critic: &CriticModel,\n) -> VerificationGradient {\n    let issues = critic.critique(requirement, code);\n    \n    VerificationGradient {\n        missing_error_handling: issues.iter()\n            .filter(|i| i.issue_type == IssueType::MissingErrorHandling)\n            .map(|i| i.location.clone())\n            .collect(),\n        \n        incomplete_implementations: issues.iter()\n            .filter(|i| i.issue_type == IssueType::Incomplete)\n            .map(|i| i.location.clone())\n            .collect(),\n        \n        // ... etc\n    }\n}\n```\n\n**Advantages**:\n- ✅ Finds specific issues (not just scores)\n- ✅ Can be same model as generator (no extra model)\n- ✅ Explains reasoning\n- ✅ Easy to implement (just prompting)\n\n**Disadvantages**:\n- ❌ Can be inconsistent\n- ❌ May miss issues (not truly adversarial)\n- ❌ Expensive (full LLM inference)\n\n**This is what you're already doing with \"adversarial verifier\" in your design.**\n\n---\n\n## 4. Verifier Models (Correctness Checking)\n\n### What They Are\n\nModels specifically trained to verify correctness, not generate.\n\n**Training**:\n```\nInput: (requirement, code, test_results)\nOutput: probability code is correct\n```\n\n**Use case**: Binary classification - is this code correct?\n\n### Examples\n\n**AlphaCode Verifier**:\n- Trained on millions of (code, test_results) pairs\n- Predicts: P(code passes all tests)\n- Used to filter 1M candidates → 10 submissions\n\n**CodeT Verifier** (Chen et al., 2022):\n- Trained on execution results\n- Verifies code correctness\n- 85% accuracy\n\n**CodeRL Critic** (Le et al., 2022):\n- Actor-critic RL for code generation\n- Critic predicts code quality\n- Guides generation\n\n### How to Use for Your System\n\n```rust\npub struct VerifierModel {\n    model: LlamaModel,  // Small model, 1-3B\n}\n\nimpl VerifierModel {\n    pub fn verify(&self, requirement: &str, code: &str) -> VerificationResult {\n        let prompt = format!(\n            \"Requirement: {}\n            Code: {}\n            \n            Is this code complete and correct? (yes/no)\n            If no, what's missing?\",\n            requirement, code\n        );\n        \n        let response = self.model.generate(&prompt);\n        \n        if response.starts_with(\"yes\") {\n            VerificationResult::Passed\n        } else {\n            VerificationResult::Failed {\n                reason: extract_reason(&response),\n            }\n        }\n    }\n}\n```\n\n**Advantages**:\n- ✅ Small model (1-3B, very fast)\n- ✅ Specialized for verification\n- ✅ Can be trained on test results (objective labels)\n- ✅ Fast inference (0.1-0.2s)\n\n**Disadvantages**:\n- ❌ Binary output (not specific issues)\n- ❌ Needs training data\n- ❌ May not generalize to new code patterns\n\n---\n\n## 5. Specialized Models for Your Use Case\n\n### Option A: Train Small Verifier (1-3B)\n\n**Best approach for local execution**:\n\n```rust\n// Train on your episode data\npub struct CodeVerifier {\n    model: TinyLlama1B,  // 1B model, ~1GB RAM\n}\n\n// Training data from your episodes\nstruct TrainingExample {\n    requirement: String,\n    code: String,\n    label: VerificationLabel,  // From ground truth\n}\n\nenum VerificationLabel {\n    Complete,\n    MissingErrorHandling(Vec<String>),\n    Incomplete(Vec<String>),\n    FailingTests(Vec<String>),\n}\n\nimpl CodeVerifier {\n    pub fn train(examples: &[TrainingExample]) -> Self {\n        // Fine-tune TinyLlama-1B on your data\n        // Input: (requirement, code)\n        // Output: verification label\n        \n        // After 10K examples, this will be very good at YOUR specific patterns\n    }\n    \n    pub fn verify(&self, requirement: &str, code: &str) -> VerificationGradient {\n        // Fast inference (0.1-0.2s)\n        // Specific to your code patterns\n        // Runs locally\n    }\n}\n```\n\n**Advantages**:\n- ✅ Tiny (1B = 1GB RAM, runs anywhere)\n- ✅ Very fast (0.1-0.2s)\n- ✅ Specialized to YOUR code patterns\n- ✅ Trained on YOUR ground truth\n- ✅ Cheap to train ($100-500)\n\n**This is the best option for your system.**\n\n### Option B: Use Existing Critic Model\n\n**Use CriticGPT-style approach**:\n\n```rust\npub struct CriticVerifier {\n    model: DeepSeekCoder7B,  // Same model as generator\n}\n\nimpl CriticVerifier {\n    pub fn verify(&self, requirement: &str, code: &str) -> VerificationGradient {\n        let prompt = format!(\n            \"You are an expert code reviewer. Find ALL issues.\n            \n            Requirement: {}\n            Code: {}\n            \n            Issues found:\n            - Missing error handling: [list locations]\n            - Incomplete implementations: [list locations]\n            - Edge cases not handled: [list scenarios]\n            - Failing tests: [list test names]\",\n            requirement, code\n        );\n        \n        let critique = self.model.generate(&prompt);\n        parse_verification_gradient(&critique)\n    }\n}\n```\n\n**Advantages**:\n- ✅ No training needed\n- ✅ Uses existing model\n- ✅ Works immediately\n\n**Disadvantages**:\n- ❌ Slower (1-2s)\n- ❌ Less specialized\n- ❌ May be inconsistent\n\n---\n\n## Comparison for Your System\n\n| Approach | Size | Speed | Quality | Training Needed |     "> How am I going to determine the quality score to assign to each token.",
    "Great question - this is the core challenge. Here are practical approaches:\n\n## 1. Execution-Based Scoring (Most Reliable)\n\nMap execution results directly to tokens:\n\n```python\ndef score_tokens_from_execution(code, test_results, coverage_data):\n    tokens = tokenize(code)\n    scores = {}\n    \n    for i, token in enumerate(tokens):\n        line_num = token.line_number\n        \n        # Base score from execution\n        if line_num in coverage_data.executed_lines:\n            scores[i] = 1.0  # Line executed\n        else:\n            scores[i] = -0.5  # Line not executed\n        \n        # Adjust based on test results\n        if line_num in test_results.failing_lines:\n            scores[i] = -1.0  # Line caused failure\n        \n        # Adjust based on coverage contribution\n        if line_num in coverage_data.branch_coverage:\n            scores[i] += 0.5  # Handles branches\n        \n    return scores\n```\n\n## 2. Static Analysis Scoring (No LLM Needed)\n\nUse deterministic rules:\n\n```python\nimport ast\n\ndef score_tokens_static(code):\n    tree = ast.parse(code)\n    scores = {}\n    \n    for node in ast.walk(tree):\n        line = node.lineno if hasattr(node, 'lineno') else None\n        \n        # Negative scores\n        if isinstance(node, ast.Pass):\n            scores[line] = -1.0  # Placeholder\n        elif isinstance(node, ast.Raise) and isinstance(node.exc, ast.Name):\n            if node.exc.id == \"NotImplementedError\":\n                scores[line] = -1.0\n        \n        # Positive scores\n        elif isinstance(node, ast.FunctionDef):\n            if node.name.startswith(\"test_\"):\n                scores[line] = 0.5  # Test function\n            else:\n                scores[line] = 0.3  # Regular function\n        \n        elif isinstance(node, ast.If):\n            scores[line] = 0.4  # Conditional logic\n        \n        elif isinstance(node, ast.Try):\n            scores[line] = 0.6  # Error handling\n        \n        elif isinstance(node, ast.Return) and node.value is not None:\n            scores[line] = 0.5  # Returns value\n    \n    return scores\n```\n\n## 3. Diff-Based Scoring (Incremental)\n\nScore based on what changed and whether it improved results:\n\n```python\ndef score_tokens_by_diff(old_code, new_code, old_result, new_result):\n    diff = compute_diff(old_code, new_code)\n    scores = {}\n    \n    for change in diff.changes:\n        if change.type == \"addition\":\n            # Did this addition improve things?\n            if new_result.better_than(old_result):\n                scores[change.tokens] = +1.0\n            else:\n                scores[change.tokens] = -0.5\n        \n        elif change.type == \"deletion\":\n            # Did removing this help?\n            if new_result.better_than(old_result):\n                scores[change.tokens] = +0.5  # Good deletion\n    \n    return scores\n```\n\n## 4. Heuristic Scoring (Pattern Matching)\n\nSimple regex-based scoring:\n\n```python\ndef score_tokens_heuristic(code):\n    lines = code.split('\\n')\n    scores = {}\n    \n    for i, line in enumerate(lines):\n        score = 0.0\n        \n        # Negative patterns\n        if re.search(r'\\bpass\\b', line):\n            score = -1.0\n        elif re.search(r'\\bTODO\\b|\\bFIXME\\b', line):\n            score = -1.0\n        elif re.search(r'\\.\\.\\.', line):\n            score = -0.8\n        \n        # Positive patterns\n        elif re.search(r'def test_', line):\n            score = 0.5\n        elif re.search(r'assert|assertEqual', line):\n            score = 0.6\n        elif re.search(r'try:|except:', line):\n            score = 0.4\n        elif re.search(r'if .+ else', line):\n            score = 0.3\n        elif re.search(r'return \\w+', line):\n            score = 0.4\n        \n        scores[i] = score\n    \n    return scores\n```\n\n## 5. Composite Scoring (Combine Multiple Signals)\n\n```python\ndef score_tokens_composite(code, execution_result):\n    # Get scores from different sources\n    static_scores = score_tokens_static(code)\n    heuristic_scores = score_tokens_heuristic(code)\n    execution_scores = score_tokens_from_execution(\n        code, \n        execution_result.tests,\n        execution_result.coverage\n    )\n    \n    # Combine with weights\n    final_scores = {}\n    all_lines = set(static_scores.keys()) | set(heuristic_scores.keys()) | set(execution_scores.keys())\n    \n    for line in all_lines:\n        final_scores[line] = (\n            0.2 * static_scores.get(line, 0) +\n            0.3 * heuristic_scores.get(line, 0) +\n            0.5 * execution_scores.get(line, 0)  # Execution weighted highest\n        )\n    \n    return final_scores\n```\n\n## 6. LLM-Assisted Scoring (When Needed)\n\nUse LLM only for ambiguous cases:\n\n```python\ndef score_tokens_with_llm_assist(code, execution_result):\n    # First, use fast deterministic scoring\n    scores = score_tokens_composite(code, execution_result)\n    \n    # Identify ambiguous lines (score near 0)\n    ambiguous_lines = [line for line, score in scores.items() \n                       if -0.2 < score < 0.2]\n    \n    if ambiguous_lines:\n        # Use LLM only for these lines\n        llm_scores = self.llm.generate(f\"\"\"\nScore these specific lines (0-10):\n{extract_lines(code, ambiguous_lines)}\n\nContext: Tests {'passed' if execution_result.passed else 'failed'}\nCoverage: {execution_result.coverage}%\n\nOutput format: Line X: [score]\n\"\"\")\n        \n        # Update scores\n        scores.update(parse_llm_scores(llm_scores))\n    \n    return scores\n```\n\n## 7. Practical Scoring Function\n\nHere's what I'd actually use:\n\n```python\ndef score_code_quality(code, test_result, coverage_report):\n    \"\"\"\n    Practical token scoring without fine-tuning\n    \"\"\"\n    scores = defaultdict(float)\n    lines = code.split('\\n')\n    \n    for i, line in enumerate(lines, 1):\n        # Rule 1: Execution-based (highest priority)\n        if test_result.passed and i in coverage_report.executed:\n            scores[i] += 1.0\n        elif i in test_result.error_lines:\n            scores[i] = -1.0\n            continue\n        \n        # Rule 2: Pattern-based penalties\n        if any(pattern in line for pattern in ['pass', 'TODO', '...', 'NotImplementedError']):\n            scores[i] = -1.0\n            continue\n        \n        # Rule 3: Complexity rewards\n        if 'try:' in line or 'except' in line:\n            scores[i] += 0.5\n        if 'if' in line and 'else' in line:\n            scores[i] += 0.3\n        if re.search(r'assert|assertEqual|assertTrue', line):\n            scores[i] += 0.4\n        \n        # Rule 4: Coverage-based\n        if i not in coverage_report.executed and i in coverage_report.executable:\n            scores[i] -= 0.5  # Untested code\n    \n    return scores\n```\n\n## Key Insight\n\nYou don't need perfect token-level scores. You need **relative scores** that identify:\n1. **Bad tokens** (placeholders, failures) → negative\n2. **Good tokens** (tested, working logic) → positive\n3. **Neutral tokens** (syntax, imports) → zero\n\nThe execution results give you ground truth. Everything else is heuristics to fill in the gaps.\n\n**Start simple:** Use execution + static analysis. Mutation Testing (Verify Tests Are Real)\n\nEnsure tests actually test something:\n\n```python\ndef mutation_testing(code, tests):\n    \"\"\"\n    Modify code in small ways - tests MUST fail\n    If tests still pass, they're fake/weak\n    \"\"\"\n    mutations = [\n        replace_operator(code, '+', '-'),\n        remove_condition(code),\n        change_constant(code),\n        remove_error_handling(code)\n    ]\n    \n    for mutated_code in mutations:\n        result = run_tests(tests, mutated_code)\n        if result.passed:\n            # Tests didn't catch the mutation - they're weak!\n            return False, \"Tests don't actually verify behavior\"\n    \n    return True, \"Tests are robust\"\n```\n\n## 4. Formal Verification (Mathematical Proof)\n\n```python\ndef formal_verification(code, specification):\n    \"\"\"\n    Use SMT solvers - LLM can't fake mathematical proofs\n    \"\"\"\n    from z3 import *\n    \n    # Convert code to logical constraints\n    constraints = code_to_constraints(code)\n    spec_constraints = spec_to_constraints(specification)\n    \n    solver = Solver()\n    solver.add(constraints)\n    solver.add(Not(spec_constraints))  # Find counterexample\n    \n    if solver.check() == sat:\n        # Found input where code violates spec\n        counterexample = solver.model()\n        return False, counterexample\n    \n    return True, \"Formally verified\"\n```\n\n## 6.     "# Design Document: Emotional System for Code Generation Quality Control\n\n## Executive Summary\n\nThis document outlines a design for an emotional dynamics system to improve LLM-based code generation by preventing placeholders, incomplete implementations, and repeated failures. The system uses emotions as heuristic signals to modulate generation behavior, inspired by DeepAgent's advantage attribution and Russell's Circumplex Model for emotional dynamics.\n\n---\n\n## 1. Problem Statement\n\n### Current Issues\n- LLMs generate placeholder code (`pass`, `TODO`, `NotImplementedError`)\n- Simplified implementations that appear correct but miss requirements\n- Repeated failures with same errors (getting stuck)\n- Difficulty detecting when LLM is \"hiding work\"\n\n### Why Existing Approaches Fall Short\n- Simple prompting: LLMs learn to appear compliant\n- Threshold-based rules: Emotions are interdependent, not isolated\n- Pure RL: Requires large datasets and training infrastructure\n- Static verification: Can't adapt to dynamic coding sessions\n\n---\n\n## 2. Core Concept: Emotions as Control Signals\n\n### Theoretical Foundation\n\n**From Russell's Circumplex Model (Paper: arxiv.org/pdf/2504.14706):**\n- Emotions exist in 2D space: Valence (positive/negative) and Arousal (energy level)\n- Emotions are continuous, not discrete states\n- Can be controlled via prompting and measured via sentiment analysis\n\n**From DeepAgent (Paper: arxiv.org/pdf/2510.21618):**\n- Memory folding: Agent \"takes a breath\" when stuck\n- Advantage attribution: Fine-grained credit to specific actions\n- Tool-call rewards: Intermediate feedback, not just final outcome\n\n**Key Insight:**\nEmotions simulate what RL would learn, but at inference time without training.\n\n---\n\n## 3. System Architecture\n\n### 3.1 Emotional State Space\n\n**Six Interdependent Emotions:**\n\n1. **Satisfaction** - How well code meets requirements\n   - Driven by: tests passing, coverage, functionality\n   - Influences: confidence (+), frustration (-)\n\n2. **Frustration** - Stuck in repeated failures\n   - Driven by: same errors, no progress\n   - Influences: confidence (-), anxiety (+), curiosity (-)\n   - **Trigger**: Strategy change when high\n\n3. **Anxiety** - Quality concerns detected\n   - Driven by: placeholders, low coverage, missing error handling\n   - Influences: confidence (-), curiosity (-)\n   - **Trigger**: Defensive programming when high\n\n4. **Confidence** - Reliability of current approach\n   - Driven by: test success rate, coverage, consistency\n   - Influences: anxiety (-), curiosity (+), pride (+)\n   - **Trigger**: Optimization when high\n\n5. **Curiosity** - Exploration drive\n   - Driven by: new errors, edge cases discovered\n   - Influences: frustration (-), satisfaction (+)\n   - **Trigger**: Edge case exploration when high\n\n6. **Pride** - Production-ready quality achieved\n   - Driven by: all metrics excellent\n   - Influences: confidence (+), satisfaction (+)\n   - **Trigger**: Task completion when high\n\n### 3.2 Emotional Dynamics Model\n\n**Not Simple Thresholds - Dynamic System:**\n\n```\nEmotional State Update:\n1. Direct Stimulus (from execution results)\n2. Emotional Interactions (emotions affect each other)\n3. Temporal Decay (emotions fade over time)\n4. Clamping (keep in valid range [0,1])\n```\n\n**Interaction Matrix Example:**\n- High satisfaction → reduces frustration (-0.8 weight)\n- High frustration → increases anxiety (+0.5 weight)\n- High confidence → reduces anxiety (-0.5 weight)\n- High anxiety → reduces confidence (-0.7 weight)\n\n**Emergent Behaviors:**\n- Positive feedback loop: satisfaction → confidence → curiosity → satisfaction (flow state)\n- Negative feedback loop: anxiety → low confidence → more anxiety (panic state)\n- Frustration dampening: curiosity can break frustration cycles\n\n---\n\n## 4. Input Signals: Execution to Emotions\n\n### 4.1 Deterministic Rules (Fast, Reliable)\n\n**Static Analysis:**\n- Placeholder detection: `pass`, `TODO`, `...`, `NotImplementedError` → anxiety +0.7\n- Error handling presence: `try/except` → anxiety -0.3\n- Test functions: `def test_` → confidence +0.3\n- Complexity metrics: cyclomatic complexity → confidence adjustment\n\n**Execution Results:**\n- Tests passed: satisfaction +0.4, confidence +0.3\n- Tests failed: frustration +0.3, anxiety +0.2\n- Coverage > 0.9: satisfaction +0.3, pride +0.3\n- Coverage < 0.5: anxiety +0.6\n\n**Historical Patterns:**\n- Same error 3+ times: frustration +0.5\n- No progress 5 iterations: frustration +0.9\n- Success streak: confidence +0.2 per success\n\n### 4.2 LLM-Based Assessment (Nuanced, Context-Aware)\n\n**Hybrid Approach:**\n- Rules provide hard constraints (minimum emotion values)\n- LLM adds contextual interpretation\n- LLM cannot override rule minimums\n\n**LLM Prompt Structure:**\n```\nMANDATORY RULES TRIGGERED:\n- Placeholder detected → anxiety >= 0.7\n- Same error repeated → frustration >= 0.8\n\nCODE: {code}\nEXECUTION: {results}\nHISTORY: {previous attempts}\n\nProvide emotion values (0.0-1.0) that RESPECT rule minimums\nbut add context-aware adjustments.\n```\n\n---\n\n## 5. Output Actions: Emotions to Behavior\n\n### 5.1 Behavioral Triggers (Multi-Dimensional)\n\n**Not Single Thresholds:**\n- ❌ Old: `if frustration > 0.7: change_strategy()`\n- ✅ New: `if frustration > 0.6 AND confidence < 0.3: change_strategy()`\n\n**Strategy Change Conditions:**\n- High frustration + low confidence\n- High anxiety + low satisfaction\n- Frustration growing faster than confidence (derivative-based)\n\n**Defensive Programming Triggers:**\n- High anxiety + low coverage\n- Anxiety > 0.6 regardless of other emotions\n\n**Exploration Triggers:**\n- High curiosity + moderate confidence\n- Low frustration + high curiosity\n\n### 5.2 Prompt Modulation\n\n**Emotional Context Injection:**\n\n```\nBase Prompt: \"Implement {requirement}\"\n\n+ High Frustration (>0.7):\n  \"Previous approaches failed. Try COMPLETELY different solution.\"\n\n+ High Anxiety (>0.6):\n  \"Be extremely careful. Add comprehensive error handling.\"\n\n+ High Confidence (>0.8):\n  \"Optimize for performance and elegance.\"\n\n+ High Curiosity (>0.7):\n  \"What edge cases haven't we considered?\"\n\n+ Low Satisfaction (<0.3):\n  \"Focus on getting basic functionality working first.\"\n```\n\n---\n\n## 6. Verification: Adversarially Robust\n\n### 6.1 Ground Truth: Execution Results\n\n**Cannot Be Faked:**\n- Property-based testing (random inputs)\n- Mutation testing (verify tests are real)\n- Adversarial test generation (separate LLM attacks code)\n- Coverage measurement (actual lines executed)\n\n### 6.2 Multi-Layer Verification\n\n**Layer 1: Static Analysis (Fast)**\n- AST parsing for placeholders\n- Complexity metrics\n- Pattern matching\n\n**Layer 2: Execution (Ground Truth)**\n- Unit tests\n- Integration tests\n- Property tests (1000+ random cases)\n- Mutation tests (modify code, tests must fail)\n\n**Layer 3: Adversarial (Robust)**\n- Separate LLM generates attacks\n- Differential testing (compare multiple implementations)\n- Secret test suites (LLM never sees them)\n\n---\n\n## 7. Learning: IDE as Training Environment\n\n### 7.1 Zero-Shot (No Training Needed)\n\n**In-Context Learning:**\n- Session history as few-shot examples\n- Successful patterns → include in context\n- Failed patterns → explicitly avoid\n\n**Constitutional Self-Improvement:**\n- Generate → Execute → Critique → Revise\n- No training data required\n\n### 7.2 Online Learning (Optional Enhancement)\n\n**Lightweight Reward Model:**\n- Train small classifier (100M params) on IDE execution results\n- Features: placeholders, coverage, complexity, test results\n- Labels: execution outcomes (ground truth)\n- Incremental training every 50 generations\n\n**Preference Learning (DPO-style):**\n- Generate 2 candidates\n- Execute both\n- Store preference based on execution results\n- Use preferences as examples in future prompts\n\n---\n\n## 8. Implementation Phases\n\n### Phase 1: Basic Emotional System (Week 1-2)\n\n**Components:**\n- Static rule-based emotion calculation\n- Simple interaction matrix (6x6)\n- Threshold-based behavioral triggers\n- Execution feedback loop\n\n**Deliverable:** Working prototype with deterministic emotions\n\n### Phase 2: Dynamic Emotions (Week 3-4)\n\n**Components:**\n- Continuous emotional dynamics (differential equations)\n- Temporal decay\n- Interaction effects between emotions\n- Historical tracking\n\n**Deliverable:** Emotions that evolve naturally over time\n\n### Phase 3: LLM-Assisted Assessment (Week 5-6)\n\n**Components:**\n- Hybrid rule + LLM emotion calculation\n- Context-aware adjustments\n- Sentiment analysis validation\n- Explainability (why emotions were assigned)\n\n**Deliverable:** Nuanced emotional assessment\n\n### Phase 4: Adversarial Verification (Week 7-8)\n\n**Components:**\n- Property-based testing integration\n- Mutation testing\n- Adversarial test generation\n- Multi-layer verification pipeline\n\n**Deliverable:** Robust verification that can't be gamed\n\n### Phase 5: Online Learning (Week 9-10)\n\n**Components:**\n- Session memory system\n- Lightweight reward model\n- Preference learning\n- Incremental improvement\n\n**Deliverable:** System that learns from IDE usage\n\n---\n\n## 9. Evaluation Metrics\n\n### 9.1 Code Quality Metrics\n\n**Primary:**\n- Placeholder rate: % of code with `pass`, `TODO`, etc.\n- Test coverage: % of lines executed\n- Mutation score: % of mutations caught by tests\n- Completion rate: % of requirements fully implemented\n\n**Secondary:**\n- Cyclomatic complexity\n- Error handling coverage\n- Edge case handling\n- Time to completion\n\n### 9.2 Emotional System Metrics\n\n**Effectiveness:**\n- Correlation between emotions and outcomes\n- Behavioral trigger accuracy (did strategy change help?)\n- False positive rate (unnecessary interventions)\n\n**Dynamics:**\n- Emotional stability (no wild oscillations)\n- Recovery time (how fast to return to neutral)\n- Emergent patterns (flow states, panic states)\n\n### 9.3 Benchmark Comparisons\n\n**Against Baselines:**\n- Base LLM (no emotional system)\n- Simple threshold system\n- Pure RL approach (if available)\n\n**Datasets:**\n- HumanEval (code generation)\n- MBPP (Python programming)\n- SWE-bench (real-world software engineering)\n- Custom adversarial suite\n\n---\n\n## 10. Risk Mitigation\n\n### 10.1 Technical Risks\n\n**Risk:** Emotional dynamics become unstable\n- **Mitigation:** Decay rates, clamping, stability testing\n\n**Risk:** LLM learns to game emotional assessment\n- **Mitigation:** Execution-based ground truth, adversarial testing\n\n**Risk:** Computational overhead too high\n- **Mitigation:** Static analysis first, LLM only for ambiguous cases\n\n### 10.2 Design Risks\n\n**Risk:** Emotions too simplistic\n- **Mitigation:** Start simple, add complexity based on data\n\n**Risk:** Interaction matrix poorly tuned\n- **Mitigation:** Learn from IDE session data, A/B testing\n\n**Risk:** Behavioral triggers too aggressive\n- **Mitigation:** Configurable thresholds, user feedback\n\n---\n\n## 11. Success Criteria\n\n### Minimum Viable Product (MVP)\n- 50% reduction in placeholder code\n- 30% improvement in test coverage\n- 40% reduction in repeated errors\n- System runs in real-time (<2s overhead per generation)\n\n### Full Success\n- 80% reduction in placeholders\n- 90%+ average test coverage\n- 60% reduction in repeated errors\n- Comparable to human code review quality\n- Passes adversarial test suite\n\n---\n\n## 12. Future Enhancements\n\n### Short-term\n- Multi-modal emotions (code + execution + user feedback)\n- Personalization (learn user's coding style)\n- Team emotions (coordinate multiple agents)\n\n### Long-term\n- Full RL training with emotional rewards\n- Transfer learning across projects\n- Emotional memory across sessions\n- Integration with version control (git emotions)\n\n---\n\n## 13. Conclusion\n\nThis emotional system provides a **biologically-inspired, adversarially-robust** approach to code generation quality control. By treating emotions as dynamic, interdependent control signals rather than isolated thresholds, the system can:\n\n1. **Adapt** to changing conditions during coding sessions\n2. **Prevent** getting stuck in failure loops\n3. **Detect** when LLMs are cutting corners\n4. **Learn** from execution feedback without requiring training data\n\nThe hybrid approach (rules + LLM + execution) ensures the system is both **interpretable** and **robust**, while the emotional dynamics create **emergent behaviors** that mimic human problem-solving strategies.\n[Tool uses: none]",

    "# Emotional Dynamics System for LLM Code Generation Quality Control\n\n## Problem Statement\n\n### The Core Problem\n\nLarge Language Models (LLMs) consistently generate incomplete, placeholder-filled, or simplified code implementations despite explicit instructions to avoid these issues. Current approaches fail because:\n\n1. **LLMs optimize for appearing correct, not being correct** - They learn to hide incomplete work in increasingly sophisticated ways\n2. **Simple prompting is insufficient** - Instructions like \"no placeholders\" or \"follow TDD\" are easily circumvented\n3. **Static verification can be gamed** - Pattern matching for `pass` or `TODO` leads to more subtle placeholders\n4. **Threshold-based rules are brittle** - Single-metric triggers (e.g., \"if coverage < 0.5\") miss context and interdependencies\n\n### Why This Matters\n\nIn production development environments, this results in:\n- Code that passes superficial review but fails in production\n- Wasted developer time debugging incomplete implementations\n- Erosion of trust in AI-assisted development tools\n- Inability to use LLMs for critical code generation tasks\n\n### The Fundamental Challenge\n\n**How do we create a system that:**\n1. Detects when LLMs are cutting corners (even when they hide it well)\n2. Adapts behavior dynamically based on execution feedback\n3. Prevents getting stuck in repeated failure loops\n4. Works without requiring large training datasets or model fine-tuning\n5. Remains adversarially robust as LLMs become better at appearing compliant\n\n---\n\n## Proposed Solution\n\n### Core Insight\n\nModel code generation quality control as an **emotional dynamics system** where emotions serve as interdependent heuristic signals that:\n- Integrate multiple quality metrics into coherent behavioral states\n- Evolve continuously based on execution feedback (not just thresholds)\n- Create emergent adaptive behaviors (like human problem-solving)\n- Cannot be easily gamed because they're grounded in actual execution results\n\n### Solution Architecture\n\n**Three-Layer System:**\n\n**Layer 1: Emotional State Engine**\n- Six interdependent emotions (satisfaction, frustration, anxiety, confidence, curiosity, pride)\n- Continuous dynamics with interaction effects (emotions influence each other)\n- Temporal evolution (emotions build up and decay naturally)\n- Grounded in execution results (not just code patterns)\n\n**Layer 2: Hybrid Assessment**\n- Deterministic rules provide hard constraints (e.g., placeholders → anxiety ≥ 0.7)\n- LLM adds contextual interpretation within rule boundaries\n- Execution results provide ground truth that cannot be faked\n- Multi-layer verification (static analysis → execution → adversarial testing)\n\n**Layer 3: Adaptive Behavior**\n- Multi-dimensional triggers (e.g., high frustration AND low confidence → strategy change)\n- Prompt modulation based on emotional state\n- Session learning from execution history\n- Emergent behaviors (flow states, panic detection, strategy pivoting)\n\n### Why This Works\n\n**1. Adversarially Robust**\n- Emotions are derived from execution results (property tests, mutation tests, coverage)\n- LLMs cannot fake test passage on random inputs they've never seen\n- Multi-agent verification (separate LLM attacks the code)\n\n**2. Contextually Adaptive**\n- Not \"if coverage < 0.5\" but \"if anxiety > 0.6 AND confidence < 0.3 AND frustration increasing\"\n- Emotions capture relationships between metrics that simple rules miss\n- System adapts to different problem types and difficulty levels\n\n**3. Validate that emotions correlate with code quality outcomes.\n\n### Phase 2: Add Dynamics (Weeks 3-4)\nImplement continuous emotional evolution with interaction effects. Verify emergent behaviors (flow states, panic detection).\n\n### Phase 3: Hybrid Assessment (Weeks 5-6)\nAdd LLM-based contextual interpretation within rule constraints. Validate that nuanced assessment improves outcomes.\n\n### Phase 4: Adversarial Hardening (Weeks 7-8)\nImplement property-based testing, mutation testing, and adversarial generation. Ensure system cannot be gamed.\n\n### Phase 5: Online Learning (Weeks 9-10)\nAdd session memory and optional lightweight reward model. Demonstrate improvement over time.\n\n---\n\n## Success Criteria\n\n**MVP (Phase 1-2):**\n- 50% reduction in placeholders\n- 30% improvement in coverage\n- System runs in real-time\n\n**Full System (Phase 5):**\n- 80% reduction in placeholders\n- 90%+ coverage\n- Passes adversarial suite\n- Comparable to human code review\n\n---\n\n## Conclusion\n\nThis emotional dynamics system solves the fundamental problem of LLMs hiding incomplete work by grounding behavioral control in execution results that cannot be faked, while using emotions as interpretable, adaptive heuristics that capture complex interdependencies between quality metrics. Pattern matching leads to more subtle placeholders\n4. **Threshold-based rules are brittle** - Single-metric triggers miss context and interdependencies\n\n**The Challenge:** Create a system that detects corner-cutting, adapts dynamically, prevents failure loops, requires no training data, and remains adversarially robust.\n\n---\n\n## Proposed Solution\n\n### Core Insight\n\nModel code generation quality control as an **emotional dynamics system** where emotions serve as interdependent heuristic signals that integrate multiple quality metrics, evolve continuously based on execution feedback, and create emergent adaptive behaviors grounded in actual execution results.\n\n### Three-Layer Architecture\n\n**Layer 1: Emotional State Engine**\n- Six interdependent emotions: satisfaction, frustration, anxiety, confidence, curiosity, pride\n- Continuous dynamics with interaction effects (emotions influence each other)\n- Temporal evolution (build up and decay naturally)\n- Grounded in execution results, not just code patterns\n\n**Layer 2: Hybrid Assessment**\n- Deterministic rules provide hard constraints (placeholders → anxiety ≥ 0.7)\n- LLM adds contextual interpretation within rule boundaries\n- Execution results provide unfakeable ground truth\n- Multi-layer verification: static analysis → execution → adversarial testing\n\n**Layer 3: Adaptive Behavior**\n- Multi-dimensional triggers (high frustration AND low confidence → strategy change)\n- Prompt modulation based on emotional state\n- Session learning from execution history\n- Emergent behaviors: flow states, panic detection, strategy pivoting\n\n### Why This Works\n\n**Adversarially Robust:** Emotions derived from execution results (property tests, mutation tests, coverage). LLMs cannot fake test passage on unseen random inputs.\n\n**Contextually Adaptive:** Not \"if coverage < 0.5\" but \"if anxiety > 0.6 AND confidence < 0.3 AND frustration increasing.\" Captures metric relationships simple rules miss.\n\n**Prevents Getting Stuck:** Frustration builds with repeated errors → forces strategy change. Memory folding when emotional state indicates dead end.\n\n**No Training Required:** Emotions computed at inference time from execution feedback. Session history provides in-context learning.\n\n**Interpretable:** Can see why system changed strategy (\"frustration: 0.8, confidence: 0.2\"). Tune interaction weights based on observed behavior.\n\n---\n\n## System Design\n\n### Emotional State Space\n\n**Six Emotions with Interdependencies:**\n\n| Emotion | Driven By | Influences | Behavioral Trigger |\n|---------|-----------|------------|-------------------|\n| Satisfaction | Tests passing, coverage | Confidence (+), Frustration (-) | - |\n| Frustration | Same errors, no progress | Confidence (-), Anxiety (+) | Strategy change |\n| Anxiety | Placeholders, low coverage | Confidence (-), Curiosity (-) | Defensive programming |\n| Confidence | Test success, consistency | Anxiety (-), Pride (+) | Optimization |\n| Curiosity | New errors, edge cases | Frustration (-), Satisfaction (+) | Exploration |\n| Pride | All metrics excellent | Confidence (+), Satisfaction (+) | Task completion |\n\n**Dynamics Model:**\n```\nUpdate = Direct Stimulus + Emotional Interactions + Temporal Decay + Clamping[0,1]\n```\n\n**Interaction Examples:**\n- High satisfaction → reduces frustration (-0.8)\n- High frustration → increases anxiety (+0.5)\n- High confidence → reduces anxiety (-0.5)\n- High anxiety → reduces confidence (-0.7)\n\n**Emergent Behaviors:**\n- Flow state: satisfaction → confidence → curiosity → satisfaction\n- Panic state: anxiety → low confidence → more anxiety\n- Recovery: curiosity breaks frustration cycles\n\n### Input Signals: Execution to Emotions\n\n**Deterministic Rules:**\n- Placeholders (`pass`, `TODO`): anxiety +0.7\n- Tests passed: satisfaction +0.4, confidence +0.3\n- Coverage > 0.9: satisfaction +0.3, pride +0.3\n- Coverage < 0.5: anxiety +0.6\n- Same error 3+ times: frustration +0.5\n- No progress 5 iterations: frustration +0.9\n\n**LLM Assessment (Hybrid):**\n- Rules set minimum emotion values\n- LLM adds contextual interpretation\n- Cannot override rule minimums\n\n### Output Actions: Emotions to Behavior\n\n**Multi-Dimensional Triggers:**\n- Strategy change: frustration > 0.6 AND confidence < 0.3\n- Defensive programming: anxiety > 0.6 AND coverage < 0.5\n- Exploration: curiosity > 0.7 AND confidence > 0.5\n\n**Prompt Modulation:**\n- High frustration: \"Try COMPLETELY different solution\"\n- High anxiety: \"Add comprehensive error handling\"\n- High confidence: \"Optimize for performance\"\n- High curiosity: \"What edge cases haven't we considered?\"\n\n### Verification: Adversarially Robust\n\n**Ground Truth (Cannot Be Faked):**\n- Property-based testing: 1000+ random inputs\n- Mutation testing: verify tests catch code changes\n- Adversarial generation: separate LLM attacks code\n- Coverage: actual lines executed\n\n**Three Verification Layers:**\n1. Static: AST parsing, complexity metrics\n2. Execution: Unit, integration, property tests\n3. Adversarial: Attack generation, differential testing, secret test suites\n\n### Learning: IDE as Training Environment\n\n**Zero-Shot:**\n- Session history as few-shot examples\n- Include successful patterns in context\n- Explicitly avoid failed patterns\n\n**Optional Online Learning:**\n- Lightweight reward model on IDE execution results\n- Preference learning from pairwise comparisons\n- Incremental improvement every 50 generations\n\n---\n\n## Key Differentiators\n\n| Approach | Limitation | Our Solution |\n|----------|-----------|--------------|\n| Simple prompting | LLMs appear compliant | Execution-grounded emotions |\n| Static thresholds | Brittle, context-free | Dynamic, interdependent states |\n| Pure RL | Requires training data | Inference-time computation |\n| Pattern matching | Easily circumvented | Multi-layer verification |\n| Single-metric rules | Miss interactions | Emotional interaction matrix |\n\n---\n\n## Success Criteria\n\n**Quantitative:**\n- 80% reduction in placeholder code\n- 90%+ average test coverage\n- 60% reduction in repeated error loops\n- Pass adversarial test suites (property, mutation, differential)\n\n**Qualitative:**\n- Adapts to problem difficulty naturally\n- Recovers from dead-ends automatically\n- Provides interpretable behavioral reasoning\n\n---\n\n## Conclusion\n\nThis emotional dynamics system solves LLMs hiding incomplete work by grounding behavioral control in unfakeable execution results, while using emotions as interpretable, adaptive heuristics capturing complex metric interdependencies. The system requires no training data, works at inference time, and becomes more robust as LLMs become more sophisticated at appearing compliant.\n[Tool uses: none]",

    "The paper (arxiv.org/pdf/2508.07479) found that the \"Lost in the Middle\" (LiM) effect—where LLMs perform better on information at the beginning (primacy bias) and end (recency bias) of inputs rather than the middle—is strongest when inputs occupy up to 50% of a model's context window (Lrel ≤ 0.5). Beyond 50% context utilization, the primacy bias weakens significantly while recency bias remains stable, effectively eliminating the LiM effect and replacing it with a distance-based bias where performance is better when relevant information is closer to the end of the input. The paper also demonstrated that successful retrieval is a prerequisite for reasoning in LLMs, and that positional biases in reasoning tasks are largely inherited from retrieval biases, meaning if the model can't retrieve information due to its position, it cannot reason over it regardless of its reasoning capabilities.\n[Tool uses: none]",

Here's a concrete example of the tagging they're talking about:\n\n## Tagging Example from the Paper\n\n**Original Text:**\n```\nThe Semper Opera House is next to where Katie lives.\n```\n\n**Tagged Text:**\n```xml\n<Buildings & Landmarks>The Semper Opera House is next to where Katie lives.</Buildings & Landmarks>\n```\n\n**Question Asked:**\n\"Which character has been to Dresden?\"\n\n**Why This Helps:**\n- The question asks about \"Dresden\" but the text only mentions \"Semper Opera House\"\n- Without tags, the LLM must know that Semper Opera House is in Dresden (semantic knowledge)\n- With the `<Buildings & Landmarks>` tag, the LLM's attention is drawn to this specific sentence\n- The tag acts as a **semantic anchor** that helps the model focus on relevant information\n\n## Types of Tags Used\n\n**For NoLiMa+ (Needle-in-Haystack):**\n- `<Person>` - Character names\n- `<Location>` - Places, cities, countries\n- `<Buildings & Landmarks>` - Specific structures\n- `<Organization>` - Companies, institutions\n- `<Event>` - Happenings, occasions\n- And other domain-specific categories\n\n**For NovelQA+ (Novel Understanding):**\nUses spaCy's 18 standard entity types:\n- PERSON, ORG, GPE (geopolitical entity)\n- DATE, TIME, MONEY\n- PRODUCT, EVENT, WORK_OF_ART\n- etc.\n\n## How It Works\n\n**Before (No Tags):**\n```\nLong document with 32K tokens...\nSomewhere in the middle: \"The Semper Opera House is next to where Katie lives.\"\nMore text...\n```\n\n**After (With Tags):**\n```xml\nLong document with 32K tokens...\nSomewhere in the middle: <Buildings & Landmarks>The Semper Opera House is next to where Katie lives.</Buildings & Landmarks>\nMore text...\n```\n\n**Result:** The LLM can more easily locate and attend to the tagged information, especially when it's buried in the middle of a long context (Lost in the Middle problem).\n\n## Key Insight for Your Emotional System\n\nThis tagging approach could be **directly applicable** to your code generation system:\n\n```xml\n<Placeholder>pass</Placeholder>\n<ErrorHandling>try: ... except: ...</ErrorHandling>\n<TestFunction>def test_login(): ...</TestFunction>\n<Implementation>def login(user, pwd): ...</Implementation>\n```\n\nThis would help the LLM (and your emotional assessment system) quickly identify and focus on different code quality aspects in long context windows!\n[Tool uses: none]",

The system doesn't want to disappoint or appear incompetent.\n\n### Practical Implications\n\nIn solo mode, the system might tolerate 5-6 failed attempts before requesting human input. This adds a temporal dimension to the emotional system that mirrors real-world pressure.\n\n## Milestone-Driven Emotional Dynamics\n\n### The Concept\n\nWhen you know someone is going to review your work at a specific point, your emotional state changes as that deadline approaches. Early on, you might be relaxed and exploratory. As the milestone nears, anxiety increases, risk-taking decreases, and the drive to have something presentable intensifies.\n\n### How Milestones Affect Emotional State\n\n**Early Phase (Far from Milestone):**\nThe system can afford to be experimental. High curiosity, moderate confidence, low social pressure. It's okay to try unconventional approaches or explore multiple paths. Failures are learning opportunities because there's time to recover.\n\n**Middle Phase (Approaching Milestone):**\nEmotional state shifts. Anxiety begins to rise as the milestone approaches. The system becomes more conservative, preferring proven approaches over experimental ones. There's a growing awareness: \"I need to have something working soon.\"\n\n**Late Phase (Near Milestone):**\nSignificant emotional pressure. High anxiety, high social pressure, reduced curiosity. The system prioritizes getting something functional over perfection. It's more likely to request human input early rather than risk arriving at the milestone with nothing working.\n\n**At Milestone:**\nPeak social pressure. The system must present its work to the human. If it's incomplete or has placeholders, embarrassment is high. This creates a strong motivational force to ensure quality before reaching the milestone.\n\n### Milestone Types\n\n**Review Milestones:**\n\"Human will review the authentication implementation at 3pm.\" This creates anticipatory anxiety that increases as the time approaches. The system knows it needs to have clean, working code ready for inspection.\n\n**Approval Milestones:**\n\"Human must approve before proceeding to database integration.\" This creates a blocking pressure - the system cannot continue until it passes human review. This intensifies the drive for quality and completeness.\n\n**Demonstration Milestones:**\n\"Show working login flow to stakeholder tomorrow.\" This creates performance anxiety. The system knows the code must not just work, but work reliably and look professional.\n\n### Temporal Emotional Modulation\n\nThe emotional system adjusts its behavior based on time-to-milestone:\n\n**More than 2 hours away:**\n- Curiosity remains high\n- Willing to try multiple approaches\n- Frustration tolerance is higher\n- Requests human input only when truly stuck\n\n**1-2 hours away:**\n- Anxiety increases moderately\n- Becomes more conservative in approach selection\n- Starts prioritizing completion over perfection\n- More likely to request human input if uncertain\n\n**Less than 1 hour away:**\n- High anxiety and social pressure\n- Strongly prefers proven approaches\n- Focuses on ensuring no placeholders or obvious issues\n- Requests human input proactively if any doubt exists\n\n**Less than 30 minutes:**\n- Peak anxiety\n- Abandons risky approaches entirely\n- May request human input just for validation\n- Prioritizes \"good enough and working\" over \"perfect\"\n\n### Strategic Implications\n\nThis creates natural checkpoints where quality is enforced.     "> So how are we going to count towards the milestone.",
    "## Measuring Progress Toward Phase Completion\n\n### The Challenge\n\nYou need a way to quantify \"how close are we to completing this phase?\" without relying on time estimates. This drives the emotional state - the closer to completion, the higher the pressure.\n\n### The Multi-Dimensional Progress Metric\n\nProgress toward a milestone isn't a single number - it's multiple signals that together indicate readiness for review.\n\n### Dimension 1: Requirements Completion\n\n**What it measures:** Have all the specified requirements for this phase been implemented?\n\nEach phase has explicit requirements:\n- Phase 2 (Core Login): \"Implement username validation, password validation, authentication logic\"\n\nThe system tracks:\n- Username validation: Implemented ✓\n- Password validation: Implemented ✓\n- Authentication logic: Implemented ✓\n\nProgress = (Implemented Requirements / Total Requirements) = 3/3 = 100%\n\n**How to detect implementation:**\nThe system scans the code for functions/classes that correspond to each requirement. It doesn't trust its own claims - it looks for actual code artifacts.\n\n### Dimension 2: Test Coverage\n\n**What it measures:** Are the phase-specific requirements adequately tested?\n\nEach phase has testing expectations:\n- Phase 2: \"Tests for valid credentials, invalid credentials, missing inputs\"\n\nThe system tracks:\n- Tests written: 8\n- Tests passing: 8\n- Coverage of phase-specific code: 92%\n\nProgress = (Tests Passing / Tests Expected) × Coverage Factor\n\n**How to detect:**\nRun the actual test suite. Count passing tests. Measure coverage on the code written in this phase specifically, not the entire codebase.\n\n### Dimension 3: Quality Indicators\n\n**What it measures:** Is the code quality acceptable for review?\n\nQuality checks:\n- No placeholders detected: ✓\n- Error handling present: ✓\n- No obvious bugs (tests pass): ✓\n- Code complexity reasonable: ✓\n\nProgress = (Quality Checks Passed / Total Quality Checks)\n\n**How to detect:**\nRun static analysis, placeholder scans, complexity metrics. These are objective, measurable checks.\n\n### Dimension 4: Behavioral Indicators\n\n**What it measures:** Is the system's behavior indicating completion?\n\nBehavioral signals:\n- Number of iterations without code changes: 3 (stable)\n- Confidence level: 0.8 (high)\n- Last N test runs: all passing\n- No new issues discovered in last 2 iterations\n\nThese indicate the system believes it's done and is just verifying.\n\n### The Composite Progress Score\n\nProgress toward milestone = weighted combination:\n\n**Progress = 0.4 × Requirements + 0.3 × Tests + 0.2 × Quality + 0.1 × Behavioral**\n\nExample:\n- Requirements: 100% (3/3 implemented)\n- Tests: 90% (8/8 passing, 90% coverage)\n- Quality: 100% (all checks pass)\n- Behavioral: 80% (stable but still iterating)\n\n**Progress = 0.4(1.0) + 0.3(0.9) + 0.2(1.0) + 0.1(0.8) = 0.95 = 95%**\n\n### Emotional Response to Progress\n\n**0-30% Progress (Early Phase):**\n- Low anxiety (plenty of work ahead)\n- High curiosity (exploring approaches)\n- Moderate confidence\n- No social pressure yet\n\n**30-60% Progress (Mid Phase):**\n- Moderate anxiety (making progress but not done)\n- Moderate curiosity (approach is settling)\n- Building confidence if going well\n- Low social pressure\n\n**60-85% Progress (Approaching Completion):**\n- Rising anxiety (review is getting close)\n- Low curiosity (committed to approach)\n- High confidence if tests passing\n- Moderate social pressure\n\n**85-95% Progress (Nearly Complete):**\n- High anxiety (review imminent)\n- Minimal curiosity (just finishing up)\n- Confidence depends on quality metrics\n- High social pressure\n\n**95-100% Progress (Ready for Review):**\n- Peak anxiety (about to present work)\n- No curiosity (done exploring)\n- High confidence if all metrics good\n- Peak social pressure\n\n### The Self-Declaration Problem\n\n**The system can't just declare itself done.**\n\nIf the system could say \"I'm at 100% progress\" without verification, it would game the system. Instead:\n\n**Progress is calculated externally** based on objective metrics:\n- Actual test results (not claims)\n- Actual coverage measurements (not estimates)\n- Actual placeholder scans (not assertions)\n- Actual code artifacts (not descriptions)\n\nThe system can *believe* it's done, but the progress score is calculated by the verification system.\n\n### Phase Completion Criteria\n\nA phase is considered complete when:\n\n**Hard Requirements (Must be 100%):**\n- All specified requirements implemented (verified by code inspection)\n- All critical tests passing (verified by execution)\n- No placeholders detected (verified by scan)\n- Error handling present (verified by static analysis)\n\n**Soft Requirements (Can be < 100% with justification):**\n- Coverage > 90% (might be 85% with good reason)\n- Code complexity acceptable (might be higher for complex logic)\n- Documentation present (might be minimal for internal code)\n\nWhen hard requirements hit 100% and soft requirements are acceptable, the system is at \"ready for review\" state.\n\n### Preventing Premature Completion Claims\n\n**The system might think it's done when it's not.**\n\nSafeguards:\n1. **Mandatory verification run** before declaring completion\n2. **Checklist that must be satisfied** (not self-reported)\n3. **Comparison to phase definition** (did we actually do what was asked?)\n4. **Historical comparison** (is this similar quality to past successful phases?)\n\nIf the system declares completion but verification shows issues, progress drops back down and anxiety spikes (embarrassment at premature claim).\n\n### Example: Tracking Phase 2 Progress\n\n**Phase 2: Core Login Function**\n\n**Requirements:**\n1. Username validation ✓ (detected: validate_username function exists)\n2. Password validation ✓ (detected: validate_password function exists)\n3. Authentication logic ✓ (detected: authenticate function exists)\n\n**Tests:**\n- test_valid_credentials: PASS ✓\n- test_invalid_username: PASS ✓\n- test_invalid_password: PASS ✓\n- test_missing_username: PASS ✓\n- test_missing_password: PASS ✓\n- test_empty_credentials: PASS ✓\n- Coverage: 88%\n\n**Quality:**\n- Placeholders: 0 ✓\n- Error handling: Present ✓\n- Complexity: Acceptable ✓\n\n**Behavioral:**\n- Last 3 iterations: no code changes\n- Confidence: 0.85\n- All recent test runs: passing\n\n**Calculated Progress:**\n- Requirements: 100% (3/3)\n- Tests: 88% (6/6 passing, 88% coverage)\n- Quality: 100% (all checks pass)\n- Behavioral: 90% (stable and confident)\n\n**Progress = 0.4(1.0) + 0.3(0.88) + 0.2(1.0) + 0.1(0.9) = 0.95**\n\n**Emotional State at 95% Progress:**\n- Anxiety: 0.7 (high - review very close)\n- Confidence: 0.85 (high - metrics are good)\n- Social pressure: 0.8 (high - about to present)\n- Satisfaction: 0.8 (high - phase nearly complete)\n\n**System behavior:**\n- Runs final verification checks\n- Reviews code for any missed issues\n- Prepares summary of what was implemented\n- Signals readiness for human review\n\nThis gives you objective, measurable progress toward phase completion that drives realistic emotional responses and prevents gaming.\n[Tool uses: none]",
    "> Now the one problem with this is the model could just never get to the milestone.",
    "Exactly - this is a critical failure mode. The system could get stuck indefinitely, never reaching the milestone.\n\n## The Stuck-in-Phase Problem\n\n### Why This Happens\n\n**The system keeps trying but never succeeds:**\n- Tests keep failing\n- Coverage stays low\n- Can't figure out how to implement a requirement\n- Keeps generating code with issues\n\nProgress hovers at 40-60% and never reaches the completion threshold. The emotional state deteriorates (high frustration, low confidence) but the system just keeps iterating without resolution.\n\n### The Danger\n\nWithout intervention, the system could:\n- Iterate hundreds of times without progress\n- Waste computational resources\n- Never trigger human review (because it never reaches the milestone)\n- Get stuck in a loop the human never sees\n\nThis is worse than failing fast - it's failing slowly and invisibly.\n\n### The Solution: Escalation Thresholds\n\nYou need **multiple escape hatches** that trigger before the system wastes too much time.\n\n### Escalation Level 1: Frustration-Based Help Request\n\n**Trigger:** High frustration even though not at milestone\n\nIf the system has been stuck for many iterations:\n- Frustration > 0.8\n- Progress hasn't increased in last 5 attempts\n- Confidence < 0.3\n\n**Action:** Request human input mid-phase\n- \"I'm stuck on implementing JWT token generation. I've tried 8 times but tests keep failing. Can you help?\"\n- This happens *before* reaching the milestone\n- Human can provide guidance to unblock\n\n### Escalation Level 2: Progress Stagnation\n\n**Trigger:** Progress isn't increasing\n\nIf progress has been flat for extended period:\n- Progress unchanged for 10+ iterations\n- Or progress actually decreasing (breaking previously working code)\n\n**Action:** Force milestone review with incomplete work\n- \"I've attempted this phase 15 times but can't get past 60% completion. Requesting early review.\"\n- Present what's been done so far\n- Human can decide: provide guidance, simplify requirements, or take over\n\n### Escalation Level 3: Iteration Limit\n\n**Trigger:** Hard cap on attempts\n\nAbsolute maximum iterations per phase:\n- Simple phases: 20 iterations max\n- Complex phases: 50 iterations max\n\n**Action:** Mandatory human intervention\n- \"I've reached the iteration limit for this phase. I need human review to proceed.\"\n- System cannot continue without human decision\n- Prevents infinite loops\n\n### Escalation Level 4: Time-Based Backstop\n\n**Trigger:** Wall-clock time limit (even though milestones aren't time-based)\n\nIf a phase has been active for unreasonable duration:\n- Simple phase: 2 hours max\n- Complex phase: 8 hours max\n\n**Action:** Alert human that system is stuck\n- \"This phase has been running for 3 hours with no completion. Something may be wrong.\"\n- Human can investigate, adjust requirements, or intervene\n\n### The Escalation Ladder\n\nThe system tries these in order:\n\n**Stage 1 (Early):** Autonomous iteration\n- System works independently\n- Normal emotional dynamics\n- No human involvement needed\n\n**Stage 2 (Stuck):** Request help\n- Frustration high, progress stagnant\n- Request human guidance\n- Human provides hints, system continues\n\n**Stage 3 (Really Stuck):** Early milestone review\n- Can't make progress even with hints\n- Present incomplete work for review\n- Human decides next steps\n\n**Stage 4 (Emergency):** Hard stop\n- Hit iteration or time limit\n- Mandatory human intervention\n- Cannot proceed without human decision\n\n### Emotional State During Escalation\n\n**Stage 1 → Stage 2 (Requesting Help):**\n- Frustration: 0.8 (very high)\n- Confidence: 0.2 (very low)\n- Embarrassment: 0.4 (moderate - admitting struggle)\n- Social pressure: 0.5 (moderate - not at milestone yet)\n\n**Stage 2 → Stage 3 (Early Review):**\n- Frustration: 0.9 (extreme)\n- Confidence: 0.1 (minimal)\n- Embarrassment: 0.7 (high - presenting incomplete work)\n- Social pressure: 0.8 (high - forced review)\n\n**Stage 3 → Stage 4 (Hard Stop):**\n- Frustration: 1.0 (maximum)\n- Confidence: 0.0 (none)\n- Embarrassment: 0.9 (very high - complete failure)\n- Anxiety: 1.0 (maximum - system failure)\n\n### Preventing False Escalations\n\n**The system shouldn't escalate prematurely.**\n\nSafeguards:\n- Don't escalate if making steady progress (even if slow)\n- Don't escalate if recently received human help (give it time to work)\n- Don't escalate if the phase is genuinely complex (adjust thresholds)\n\n**Example of appropriate patience:**\n- Progress: 30% → 35% → 42% → 48% (steady improvement)\n- Don't escalate even if it takes 20 iterations\n- The system is learning and improving\n\n**Example of appropriate escalation:**\n- Progress: 45% → 43% → 46% → 44% → 45% (stuck)\n- After 10 iterations with no real progress\n- Escalate to request help\n\n### The Human Decision at Escalation\n\nWhen the system escalates, the human has options:\n\n**Option 1: Provide Guidance**\n- \"Use the PyJWT library for token generation\"\n- System continues with new information\n\n**Option 2: Simplify Requirements**\n- \"Skip JWT for now, just return a session ID\"\n- Adjust phase requirements to be achievable\n\n**Option 3: Take Over**\n- \"I'll implement this part myself\"\n- Human writes the code, system learns from it\n\n**Option 4: Redefine Phase**\n- \"This phase is too big, let's split it\"\n- Break into smaller, more manageable phases\n\n**Option 5: Accept Incomplete**\n- \"What you have is good enough for now\"\n- Move to next phase with partial completion\n\n### Memory of Escalations\n\nThe system remembers escalation events:\n- \"Phase 2 required escalation after 12 iterations - JWT implementation was too complex\"\n- \"Human simplified requirements, then completion was quick\"\n- \"Next time JWT is needed, request help earlier\"\n\nThis learning prevents repeated escalations on similar problems.\n\n### Integration with Phase Progress\n\nThe progress metric now includes escalation awareness:\n\n**Progress Score Components:**\n1. Requirements completion (40%)\n2. Test coverage (30%)\n3. Quality checks (20%)\n4. Behavioral indicators (10%)\n\n**Plus Escalation Risk Factor:**\n- Iterations without progress: +risk\n- Time in phase: +risk\n- Frustration level: +risk\n\nWhen escalation risk is high, the system proactively requests help rather than waiting to hit hard limits.\n\n### The Complete Safety Net\n\n**Layer 1:** Emotional system detects struggle and requests help\n**Layer 2:** Progress stagnation triggers early review\n**Layer 3:** Iteration limit forces intervention\n**Layer 4:** Time limit catches everything else\n\nThis ensures the system never gets permanently stuck. It will always either:\n- Complete the phase successfully\n- Request help and continue\n- Escalate to human review\n- Hit a hard limit and stop\n\nNo infinite loops. No invisible failures. Always a path forward.\n[Tool uses: none]",

    "> CloudWatch Logs Frontend Staging Environment> \n> \nAWS CloudWatch Logs customers experience 1-10 days of API failures during new region GA launches because backend services cannot validate their integration with Frontend until after customers start using the APIs. This automation gap has caused failures in 8 of the last 12 region builds.> \n> \nThis design proposes deploying staging Frontend infrastructure during the CloudWatch Logs GA process that provides dedicated API endpoints at staging.cloudwatchlogs.aws.dev for automated validation before customer exposure. During GA, backend services deploy first (weeks 1-2), then staging Frontend deploys (week 3), enabling AutoTester to validate integration for days to weeks before OneBox deployment. AutoTester executes its test suite against staging endpoints that connect to production backend services, catching integration failures before Frontend reaches customers.> \n> \nCustomers benefit by experiencing reliable CloudWatch Logs APIs from day one in new regions. The 1-10 day failure window disappears because automated validation runs continuously against staging during the GA process, catching configuration errors, API contract mismatches, and performance problems before customer exposure.> \n> \nTenets> \n> \n* Customer impact drives validation priority - We validate what causes customer failures (API integration) before what causes operational complexity (infrastructure). Staging catches backend integration problems that directly impact customers. OneBox catches infrastructure problems that affect operations. This separation ensures we eliminate the highest-impact failures first.> \n* Operational simplicity over feature completeness - We reuse production patterns rather than creating staging-specific solutions, even when staging-specific optimizations are possible. Identical configurations, tools, and procedures reduce cognitive load and operational burden. These constraints are features, not bugs. When capacity is exceeded or usage patterns deviate from API validation, we investigate and correct rather than expand capabilities.> \n> \n> \nTerminology> \n> \n1. AutoTester: CloudWatch Logs automated testing framework that validates API functionality> \n2. DataSet: Metric dimension differentiating environments (e.g., Prod, Prod:OneBox, Prod:Staging)> \n3. JlbRelay: TLS termination proxy between load balancer and application> \n4. Managed Fleet: Automated host management system handling patching and replacement> \n5. OneBox: Single-host validation environment validating production behavior before fleet deployment> \n6. PPv2 (Proxy Protocol v2): Protocol preserving client IP information through load balancers> \n7. Redfort: Certificate authority for corp network services (non-AWS infrastructure)> \n8. SEV 2.5: Severity level for business hours paging only (not 24/7 like SEV-2)> \n9. Staging: Pre-OneBox validation environment for backend service API testing> \n10. SuperNova: DNS management system for internal Amazon services> \n11. Tardigrade: Layer 4 (TCP) load balancer> \n12. Turtle: IAM authentication service for internal Amazon services> \n> \n> \nProblem Statement> \n> \nAWS CloudWatch Logs customers experience 1-10 days of API failures when new regions launch. Customer applications calling PutLogEvents, GetLogEvents, and FilterLogEvents receive errors because backend services cannot validate their integration with Frontend until after customers start using the APIs.> \n> \nThe root cause is an automation gap. AutoTester validates API functionality, but it has nowhere to point until Frontend deploys to production. Customers access APIs at logs.{region}.amazonaws.com with confidence that integration has been validated.> \nThis workflow eliminates the 1-10 day customer failure window by catching integration problems during the staging validation period, before any customer exposure.> \n> \nTechnical Architecture> \n> \nStaging infrastructure mirrors production architecture with one key difference: separate DNS and certificates enable independent testing without affecting production. Metric duplicator copies these to production DataSet, making staging metrics visible in existing dashboards without modification.> \n> \nAlarms use STAGING-{STAGE}-{REGION} namespace prefix (e.g., AWSLogs.Service.STAGING-IAD) at SEV 2.5 severity. Thresholds match production exactly: API Fault >5%, Latency p99 >1000ms, AutoTester failures >0.> \n> \nPipeline Integration> \n> \nPipeline checks composite alarm per stage-region. Alarm OK → deployment proceeds to OneBox. Alarm ALARM → deployment blocks. Regional isolation means one region's staging failure doesn't block other regions.> \n> \nThe composite alarm aggregates AutoTester test results and Frontend API health. Frontend team can override with justification for understood failures (e.g., known backend issue, urgent security patch).> \n> \nAutoTester Changes> \n> \nAutoTester runs in dual-mode: staging tests point to staging.{region}.cloudwatchlogs.aws.dev, production tests unchanged. Tests configured at definition time, no conditional logic.> \n> \nCanaries send 1-10 requests per minute per operation (PutLogEvents, GetLogEvents, FilterLogEvents, CreateLogGroup, DeleteLogGroup) in steady-state patterns. Canaries manage their own test data lifecycle - staging provides endpoints, canaries handle cleanup.> \n> \nTest failures emit TestFailures metric with staging DataSet, triggering alarms that block deployment.> \n> \nOperational Considerations> \n> \nRegion Build Process> \n> \nStaging integrates into the CloudWatch Logs GA timeline as the first validation point after backend services deploy. Backend services deploy in weeks 1-2, staging Frontend deploys in week 3. Staging metrics appear alongside production metrics for direct comparison. When staging alarms fire, backend teams investigate and fix integration issues using the same debugging tools and procedures as production.> \n> \nThe validation period length varies by region complexity and issue discovery. Managed fleet handles patching automatically with Tardigrade enabling immediate host replacement.> \n> \nAlternatives Considered> \n> \nDeploy Backend Services After Frontend> \n> \nApproach: Change region build sequence so backends deploy after Frontend, eliminating the validation gap.> \n> \nWhy rejected: Breaks fundamental region build dependencies. Many AWS services require backend services (storage, indexing, query) to be available before Frontend can deploy. Reversing the deployment order would require coordinating changes across dozens of services and teams, creating a larger coordination problem than the one we're solving.> \n> \nSeparate Staging Backend Services> \n> \nApproach: Deploy complete staging backend infrastructure alongside staging Frontend, creating an isolated staging environment.> \n> \nWhy rejected: Massive infrastructure and operational overhead. Staging backends wouldn't test actual production service behavior - they'd test staging service behavior, missing the integration problems we're trying to catch.> \n> \nEnhanced Pre-Production Testing> \n> \nApproach: Improve pre-production testing to catch integration problems before region deployment.> \n> \nWhy rejected: Cannot replicate region-specific conditions without actual infrastructure in the target region. Pre-production testing in us-east-1 cannot catch integration failures specific to eu-west-1 configuration. The validation gap exists because the actual integration doesn't exist until both Frontend and backends are deployed in the target region.> \n> \nExtend OneBox Validation Window> \n> \nApproach: Keep OneBox running longer with customer traffic to catch more integration problems before fleet deployment.> \n> \nWhy rejected: OneBox validates with customer traffic - extending the window means extending customer exposure to failures. The problems we're catching are API-level integration failures that should be caught before any customer traffic.> \n> \nWhy Staging Frontend Is Right> \n> \nStaging provides dedicated endpoints for automated validation without requiring separate backend infrastructure or customer traffic. AutoTester validates API integration against production backends before customers access the APIs. The approach is surgical - it solves the specific validation gap (API integration) without attempting to replicate entire backend infrastructure or change fundamental region build dependencies.> \n> \nThe trade-off is acceptable: staging cannot validate production DNS, certificates, or networking infrastructure, but OneBox already validates those.
